Alphabet’s advertising unit, which contributes the vast majority of the company’s revenue, has been competing in a crowded field of rivals vying for more ad dollars as lower interest rates are expected to lift the economy. “Continued strength in search is helping to dispel the negative sentiment surrounding AI’s potential impact on Google’s biggest businesses,” said Matt Stucky, chief portfolio manager at shareholder Northwestern Mutual Wealth Management. However, analysts have pointed to cautious spending from advertisers in some sectors grappling with economic uncertainty due to pressures from tariff costs and a rapidly evolving global trading landscape. Still, Wall Street expects the company to benefit from advertisers moving away from experimental ad platforms like Snapchat and others. Last week, Microsoft and SoftBank Group-backed OpenAI unveiled Atlas, an AI-powered browser aimed at directly competing with Google’s core search engine and browser stack. The launch, as Reuters earlier reported, represents one of the most significant challenges to Google’s search dominance in years and will be a key focus for investors listening for management’s response to the rising competitive threat to its most lucrative business. Still, while the ChatGPT maker and other startups like Anthropic and Perplexity are introducing new AI-powered apps to consumers, Google’s search market share appears to be steadying. “AI Overviews and AI Mode are clearly resonating with users, helping to ease fears that Google’s core search business is under threat from generative AI,” said Matt Britzman, senior equity analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown. Alphabet reported that its number of employees stood at roughly 190,000 at the end of September, up by more than 8,000 from the same period last year. Its rival Amazon said it will lay off 14,000 workers on Tuesday. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Alphabet hikes capex again after earnings beat on strong ad, cloud demand

text: The Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR) has ordered a temporary suspension of its field audit operations nationwide, a directive formalized under Revenue Memorandum Circular (RMC) No. 107-2025, issued on November 24, 2025. This move, initiated under the leadership of the new BIR Commissioner, Charlito Martin R. Mendoza, is an institutional response to concerns regarding the integrity and fairness of the tax audit process. Understanding this suspension and its implications is vital for maintaining proactive tax risk management. The primary objective of the audit suspension under RMC 107‑2025 is to enable the BIR to implement a more comprehensive internal review of its tax audit policies and procedures, strengthen internal safeguards, and ensure that the issuance of Letters of Authority (LOAs) and Mission Orders (MOs) follows the rule of law, advancing the protection of taxpayer rights. Unlike the annual “Stop Audit,” which was a fixed, short-term pause mostly affecting routine audits, the current suspension was implemented earlier, includes stronger internal controls, covers both new and ongoing audits, and will remain in effect until lifted by the Commissioner. It is crucial to note that RMC No. 107-2025 does not constitute a total freeze on all BIR examinations. The following critical and time-sensitive operations are explicitly excluded and will proceed: While the temporary suspension alleviates immediate audit pressure, the expectation is that the ensuing audit system will be more stringent and standardized. Therefore, businesses should use this period for critical internal preparation. The BIR’s directive presents an opportunity for the Bureau to implement procedural reforms and for taxpayers to reinforce their internal controls and compliance posture. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: [Ask the Tax Whiz] Temporary suspension of BIR audit: Are you affected?

text: On November 11, 2025, the De La Salle University (DLSU) Ramon V. del Rosario College of Business (RVRCOB) was awarded 4 Palmes of Excellence at the Eduniversal World Convention hosted by the Indian Institute of Management (IIM) Indore at the Indore Marriott Hotel. This puts the DLSU RVRCOB in the top 20% of 1,000 ranked business schools worldwide. Eduniversal recognized the college’s programs that combine academic rigor with real-world business experience. The 4 Palmes recognize academic excellence and regional leadership through research, sustainability, and ethical business practices. By nurturing Lasallian business leaders who make a difference, RVRCOB advances global business education excellence. This award, though very much welcome, raises challenging questions for reflections. How does a school with international influence become a global force for good? The answer requires looking beyond our own achievements to learn from institutions that have wrestled with this question too. The convention, with the theme “Bridging Purpose and Performance: Business Education as a Force for Good,” opened with Professor Himanshu Rai’s remarks and keynote. As the director of IIM Indore, he explained the role of Indore and his business school in contributing to India’s nation-building efforts. His institution holds Triple Crown accreditation, ranks among the world’s top 1% of business schools, and sits on a 193-acre campus, and plays a vital role in the development of Indore. With the efforts of the local government, the school, and the citizens, Indore has been recognized as the India’s cleanest city for seven consecutive years. Moving to his keynote, Rai chose to ground ethical leadership lessons on Vedic wisdom and ancient Sanskrit texts. Rai connected Vedic wisdom to concrete leadership failures he’d witnessed: leaders who lost themselves in performance metrics, who deflected accountability when decisions went wrong, who operated below their capacity because they feared failure more than they valued excellence. Rai calls IIM Indore as “ancient yet agile.” The phrase captures something we need to understand. The school doesn’t treat its cultural heritage as decoration or as separate from “real” business education. Indian wisdom isn’t an elective. It’s the foundation that shapes how they think about leadership, how they structure experiential learning programs, and how they evaluate what counts as success. The Vedas and the Indian heritage are taught as business education, not alongside it. The case of IIM Indore is fascinating in its paradox: it honors its tradition, yet it is considered a top global school of tomorrow. How can Filipino business schools learn from this example? At RVRCOB, we have something similar: our Lasallian tradition and our Filipino values. But do we teach them as business education or merely adjacent to it? Context-wise, the Philippines and India share characteristics. Large populations, rapid growth, collectivist cultures, family business dominance. Colonial histories creating tension between indigenous wisdom and imported models. What if Philippine business schools integrate our respective values with our cultural heritage? What if RVRCOB combines Filipino concepts with Lasallian pedagogical discipline? Filipino psychology and philosophy provide rich cultural resources. The most relevant to management, I think, are the Filipino constructs I would label as “DKL” (in part because it can be read as “dakila”) — diwa, kapwa, and loob. Loob represents the inner self, the seat of volition and authentic conviction. Kapwa captures our relational nature, the recognition that self and other are fundamentally interconnected. Diwa points toward collective consciousness, the spirit that animates groups and organizations. Similar to how Rai drew from the wisdom of the Vedas, DKL describes how Filipinos actually experience and navigate the world. A manager who cultivates loob develops genuine conviction rather than performing what they think leadership should look like. A leader who practices kapwa builds organizations where people matter as people, not as human resources. An institution animated by diwa serves purposes that transcend narrow institutional interests. DLSU’s Lasallian Reflection Framework already provides a structured approach to values-based practice through Masid-Danas (See-Experience), Suri-Nilay (Analysis-Reflection), and Taya-Kilos (Commitment-Action). These aren’t just steps in a process. Masid-Danas means being mapagpansin, genuinely attentive to what’s actually happening, not what theories predict. Suri-nilay goes deeper than standard analysis, malalim (deep), seeking integrated understanding by engaging intellect and intuition together, the capacity to grasp situations holistically, to see patterns that pure logic might miss, to develop insights then validate them iteratively. Taya-kilos is where discernment becomes action, may pananagutan, completely accountable and responsible, not action for its own sake but movement that flows from genuine understanding. The path forward requires three shifts. First, Philippine business schools need to stop treating Filipino values as supplementary to “real” business education. They are our foundations for thinking about management, leadership, and organizational purpose. Second, we need to develop pedagogical approaches that genuinely integrate these values rather than just mentioning them. IIM Indore structures entire programs around their heritage, from their Rural Engagement Program to their Himalayan Outbound Program to their workshops on Mithila traditional art forms. What would Filipino business education look like if we took our own wisdom traditions that seriously? Third, we need to root ourselves more deeply in Philippine social realities. Business education becomes a force for good when business schools become genuine partners in addressing the specific challenges facing Philippine society. RVRCOB’s 4 Palmes recognition tells us that Philippine business schools are worth recognizing globally. IIM Indore shows us one possibility: a business school that draws strength from its cultural context while meeting global standards. Our international peers are calling for us. The global picture needs the colors only we Filipinos can add. – Rappler.com Patrick Adriel H. Aure, PhD (Patch) is the founding director of the PHINMA-DLSU Center for Business and Society and Associate Professor at the Department of Management and Organization, Ramon V. del Rosario College of Business, De La Salle University. patrick.aure@dlsu.edu.ph
label: True
title: [Good Business] Business education as a global force for good

text: MANILA, Philippines – Bounty Fresh is focusing its efforts into strengthening its operations in core businesses as demand for poultry in the Philippines is expected to grow in the mid-term. The agribusiness firm’s president and chief executive officer Kenneth Cheng said on Monday, October 13, that the company does not intend to go public any time soon, and instead, focus on strengthening its domestic supply chain. “Right now we’re investing for the future. We are not only investing in new farms, we’re also investing in new plants,” he explained. Cheng did not disclose the exact figure of Bounty Fresh’s capital expenditures (capex) for the year, but he noted that the firm is allocating around half of its capex to expansion. This includes the construction of new facilities such as farms and processing plants. Plans for expansion come as consultancy firm GIRA estimates that poultry consumption in the Philippines will grow 500,000 tons every five years. This translates to a poultry consumption of 4.5 million tons by 2050, double the current 2 million tons. “Filipinos are going to eat chicken, whether the local farmers produce them or not. If we don’t produce them, it will be coming in by importation. And so this is an opportunity for the local poultry farmer, but it’s also a challenge,” Cheng said. In order to keep up with growing poultry demand, Bounty Fresh aims to sustainably strengthen its supply chain by boosting production, distribution and market reach to balance growth with demand. Cheng noted that one of the obstacles to achieving this is the limited workforce in agriculture as the youth pursue other fields. He also stressed the need to invest in the agricultural sector’s workforce to develop stockmanship and create a career pipeline that younger generations can build a career out of. The Bounty Fresh chief also underscored the need to invest in biosecurity to help the sector keep pace with the demand. Bounty Fresh is the Philippines’ second largest poultry integrator. The company estimates that it contributes around a quarter of the country’s total poultry production. Cheng added that that the Inoza Group’s recent acquisition of the Bistro Group will help integrate Bounty Fresh’s chicken business into the restaurants. Inoza Holdings of Bounty Fresh chairman Tennyson Chen acquired 22% of the Bistro Group from tycoon Andres Soriano III’s A. Soriano Corporation for P1.9 billion on October 2. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Bounty Fresh aims to strengthen operations amid growing appetite for poultry

text: CEBU, Philippines — At a funeral home in Liloan, Cebu, 31-year-old Krizza Espra searches for clothes, something decent for her children to wear in their coffins. Her arms bore visible scratches. Her face was blank, eyes distant, as if her body was there but her mind was still caught in the flood that took everything from her. Krizza lost her entire family when floodwaters swept through her sister’s home in Barangay Tamiao, Compostela, Cebu, during the onslaught of Typhoon Tino (Kalmaegi) on Tuesday morning, November 4. Originally from Barangay Cotcot, the family thought they would be safer staying in her sister’s house. “Pumunta kami doon kasi noong Odette, wala kaming tubig sa Cotcot,” she said in a trembling voice. (We went there because when Typhoon Odette struck, we had no water in Cotcot.) At around 6:30 am, floodwaters rapidly rose, forcing them onto the roof. Moments later, the structure gave way. “Magkasama kami sa bubong. Gumuho yung bubong, nahulog kami, nalalag kami,” Krizza recalled. “Apat lang kami naka-survive.” (We were all together on the roof. Then it collapsed, and we fell. Only four of us survived.) She lost nearly her entire family: her husband James Espra, 29, their children Sebastian James, 8; Alessia Isabelle, 4; and Kyle Stefan, 1; her parents Alice, 73, and Samuel Bugtai, 82; a nephew, two young cousins, and her aunt. Only four members of the extended family survived: Krizza, her cousin’s husband, her brother, and her brother’s wife. Her mother, aunt, and two children of her cousin, ages three months and three years, are still missing. “Apat pa yung missing sa amin,” she said. “Sana may tumulong para mapabilis yung pangahanap bago bumaho yung mga bangkay nila at mga agnas, makilala man lang namin, makuha sila.” (Four of our members are missing. I hope we can get some help to find and identify them before the bodies decompose.) As of 6 pm on Thursday, November 6, at least 125 people have died in Cebu due to Typhoon Tino, 108 in Cebu Province and 17 in Cebu City, according to the Emergency Operations Center (EOC). At least 63 others remain missing. Krizza says she only hopes for one thing – that rescuers continue the search so families like hers can finally bring their loved ones home and give them a proper burial. –Rappler.com
label: True
title: Typhoon Tino took everything from her

text: MANILA, Philippines – The Philippine economy grew just 4% in the third quarter of 2025 as the flood control scandal dampened investor and consumer confidence, the Philippine Statistics Authority (PSA) reported on Friday, November 7. The latest gross domestic product (GDP) print is slower than the second quarter’s 5.5% growth rate, and places the country’s average economic growth for the year so far at just 5%. The Marcos administration aims to grow the economy by 5.5% to 6.5% in 2025. The GDP print is also much lower than analysts’ expectations of around 5.3%. It marks the Philippine economy’s slowest growth since the contraction in the first quarter of 2021, during the COVID-19 pandemic. Government infrastructure spending plunged to a 14-year low of -26.2% growth amid stricter validation measures for the Department of Public Works and Highways’ projects, as well as delayed billings and disbursements for government works. These measures were implemented in light of the government’s ongoing probe into anomalous flood control projects. Department of Economy, Planning, and Development (DEPDev) Secretary Arsenio Balisacan also noted that the flood control scandal affected consumer confidence, as households postponed their purchases of durable goods. Household spending grew by just 0.5% in the third quarter. On the production side, all three major industries posted growth in the third quarter. The agriculture sector (2.8% growth) rebounded from last year’s contraction (-2.7%), but growth in industry (0.7%) and services (5.5%) slowed from the same quarter in 2024. Balisacan admitted that to meet the government’s target growth range, the economy will have to grow by around 6.8% in the fourth quarter. “Given the shocks that are happening at the moment and are expected to linger in the remaining weeks and before the year ends, that’s quite challenging,” he said. Balisacan noted that the last time public construction spending contracted by over 20% was in 2011 amid the late former president Benigno “Noynoy” Aquino III’s crackdown on corruption. Because of the loss of consumer and investor confidence, Balisacan vowed to implement “strategic interventions” to bolster trust and accelerate economic growth. These include fast-tracking social protection for vulnerable Filipinos and pursuing long-term governance reforms such as proposed amendments to the bank secrecy law. He also hopes that the government can begin disbursing funds for projects that are not tainted with corruption. “Those projects that were intended for 2025 that were already completed and are not involved with any of those red flags, they should be paid so that the resources, the funds will recirculate in the economy and create other opportunities, more opportunities,” he said. The country’s chief economist also noted that the government is underspending in key priority areas despite an increase in funding for infrastructure over the years. “The productive capacity that we had wanted to happen was muted by all this corruption because the investment in infrastructure that we are trying to ramp up is supposed to enhance the capacity of the economy to produce more, to employ more, to generate higher quality jobs,” Balisacan explained. Balisacan underscored the importance of not just merely increasing infrastructure spending, but improving the quality of spending as well. This means ensuring that public funds are spent on high-quality projects that will boost economic growth, even if it means working with a smaller budget. “So what I think lagged behind and we should have worked on harder are the governance and institutional mechanisms that would allow us to accommodate such kind of spending. And this is…I think an important lesson — that we did not focus much on equally important areas of good economic management, and it is the ecosystem that would allow us to ensure that there is consistency between policy design and implementation and outcomes,” he said. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Corruption woes drag Philippines’ economic growth to 4-year low in Q3 2025

text: Newly surfaced records obtained by Vantage Point expose how GSIS trustees, Evelina Escudero, Merceditas Gutierrez and Rita Riddle, helped usher in a dubious ₱2-billion IT deal with DBP Data Center Inc. (DCI) — a firm whose own executives later admitted to have lacked the capability in building the public sector’s social insurance institution’s core systems. What began as a push for “modernization” now reeks of impropriety and influence-peddling within a pension fund in which these ladies claim to have been mismanaged. When guardians of the public trust start behaving like brokers, institutions crumble from within. The Government Service Insurance System (GSIS), already bruised by allegations of governance lapses and flood-control controversies, now finds itself entangled in another scandal — this time involving a ₱2-billion computerization deal pushed by trustees Evelina Escudero and Rita Riddle and allegedly backed by Merceditas Gutierrez. Gutierrez and Riddle resigned from the GSIS board last month. What makes this case galling is not just the staggering amount or the timing — coming as GSIS struggles to rebuild credibility — but the audacity with which key trustees introduced and advanced a project pitched by a company that ultimately confessed it couldn’t deliver what it was promising. On September 2, 2025, representatives from DBP Data Center Incorporated (DCI) — Business Development Head Jose Enrique Singson, Project Lead Apolonia Salud Jr., and domain experts Ma. Isabel Domingo and Dennis Dizon — met with the GSIS Board of Trustees to present their information technology (IT) services. That meeting alone raised eyebrows. DCI was no mere vendor — it was a government-owned and -controlled corporation (GOCC) under the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP). Yet its delegation was allowed to pitch directly to the GSIS board, a move that blurred procurement lines and created a cozy dynamic between trustees and a potential contractor. Just two weeks later, on September 15, 2025, during the Legal Oversight Committee meeting, trustees proposed that GSIS and DCI execute a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) — fast-tracked through a board referendum which bypassed a full deliberation. For an institution managing billions in pension assets, such haste is indefensible. The trustees weren’t merely entertaining a presentation; they were laying the groundwork for a partnership that would later balloon into a ₱2-billion IT “modernization” project. Thankfully, not everyone was asleep at the switch. Vantage Point learned that on September 29, 2025, GSIS President and General Manager Jose Arnulfo “Wick” Veloso intervened during the Risk Oversight Committee meeting, requesting that approval of the MOU be deferred. Veloso, who had not attended the earlier presentations, questioned why such a significant deal had progressed without his knowledge. He requested a direct meeting with DCI’s top executives — President and Chief Executive Officer Michielson Luakian and Chief Operating Officer Jose Carmelo Porciuncula — to better understand their proposal. The meeting was scheduled for October 9, 2025. What unfolded there should have killed the deal permanently. During that October meeting, DCI executives revealed more than they intended. They described their company as a “40-year-old startup” offering IT support and staff augmentation services to various government agencies and private clients. When asked if they developed the core systems of the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP), they admitted they did not — DBP handled its own IT infrastructure. DCI merely provided manpower support “when needed.” When pressed further about their readiness to take on GSIS’s modernization, DCI’s own president conceded that “GSIS is significantly more advanced in IT than most government-owned or -controlled corporations,” and that DCI “does not have the capability to undertake the development of GSIS’s core systems.” The clincher came when Luakian stated DCI would formally withdraw its interest to avoid further delays in GSIS’s internal plans. If this were a private-sector board, the next step would be an investigation into how such a weak proposal ever made it to board-level presentation. In GSIS, however, it became another footnote in a long saga of institutional decay. After the meeting, Veloso reportedly asked who had introduced DCI to GSIS. The answer came from Vice President and Chief Information Security/Data Protection Officer Jonathan Pineda: it was trustees Riddle and Escudero. It was later learned that the deal had the backing of Gutierrez. Pineda disclosed that during the September 2 Risk Oversight Committee meeting, Riddle and Escudero had suggested that GSIS’s IT systems be “reviewed and audited by DCI,” and that an MOU be signed to facilitate an “agency-to-agency procurement.” That phrase — agency-to-agency procurement — is key. Such arrangements between government entities are exempt from public bidding under Republic Act 9184, the Government Procurement Reform Act. In theory, agency-to-agency procurements promote efficiency. In practice, they create a loophole: a way to move massive sums without competitive scrutiny. It’s not modernization; it’s maneuvering. The revelations did not stop there. Upon background check, Vantage Point discovered that DCI President Luakian — the same man who had just admitted lack of IT expertise — was previously business development head of M.E. Sicat Construction Incorporated, a DPWH contractor involved in public works projects. So, the man behind a proposed ₱2-billion IT deal for GSIS came from the same world of construction contracting now tainted by flood-control scandals. To call that a conflict of interest would be an understatement — it is a revolving door between two sectors notorious for cost overruns and patronage politics. Trustees Riddle, Escudero, and Gutierrez appear to have facilitated, endorsed, or at best tolerated a process that flirted dangerously with impropriety. Gutierrez, who recently resigned from the GSIS board and carries her own history of ethical baggage as former Philippine justice secretary and Ombudsman — should have been the first to demand due diligence. Their actions betray a disturbing inversion of duty: trustees meant to guard public funds became the very conduits for questionable partnerships. At a time when GSIS is under intense scrutiny for investment losses — which the three ladies, along with other signatories, alleged procurement opacity — and political entanglements, the last thing the institution needs is another scandal cloaked in the language of “digital transformation.” The DCI episode is symptomatic of a larger sickness in public finance: the weaponization of “modernization.” Every time an agency is caught in a scandal, it announces a grand reform project — usually IT-related, often multimillion-peso, or in this case multibillion-peso, worth. These projects rarely fix the core problem. They merely digitize dysfunction. Without ethical leadership, every system — no matter how advanced — becomes another conduit for graft. What must happen now GSIS doesn’t need a ₱2-billion IT overhaul. It needs an ethical reboot. Until the board cleans its ranks, no system — digital or human — can restore the public’s trust. Escudero, Gutierrez, and Riddle’s fingerprints on the DCI affair show that the danger to GSIS is not technological inadequacy, but moral decay. When trustees act like sales agents and former contractors pose as technological innovators, modernization becomes just another scam in bureaucratic clothing. If GSIS cannot fix that, it won’t need a new system; it will need a rescue. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: [Vantage Point] The DCI-GSIS affair: A billion-peso blunder

text: Executive Secretary Ralph Recto has declared in a statement that “better days are coming” for the Philippine economy. It arrives at a moment when President Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos Jr.’s administration is eager to showcase its wins with inflation dropping to 1.5% in November — well below the government’s target band — while major credit rating agency S&P’s reaffirmation of the country’s BBB+ rating has given Malacañang a welcome seal of external validation. Recto frames these developments as evidence of a disciplined, more transparent governance culture under Marcos Jr., pointing to asset seizures, Anti-Money Laundering Council (AMLC) freezes, and recovered kickbacks as signs that the state is finally cracking down on corruption. In his telling, low prices, a strong labor market, and a “disciplined” 2026 budget will pave the way for a stronger, more confident economy. But optimism must coexist with realism. Debt is rising faster than growth, the peso remains exposed to political shocks, and institutional credibility is still repairing itself after the turbulence of the past year. Whether the Philippines truly enters a “better, stronger” economic phase will depend, not on inflation numbers or international ratings, but on the country’s ability to confront the structural risks that soften the foundations beneath Recto’s upbeat narrative. Vantage Point does not dispute Recto’s optimistic claim. I concede that it is grounded in real macroeconomic gains, but it also sits atop a fiscal landscape that demands more caution than celebration. The same period that produced low inflation also produced a swelling national debt, which reached ₱17.56 trillion in October — a 9.62% increase from the previous year, and much faster than the economy’s own expansion. Gross domestic product (GDP) growth of roughly 5.2% cannot keep pace with the speed at which obligations are piling up, particularly as the peso softens from ₱56.145 to ₱58.58 to the dollar over the past year. That depreciation alone has inflated the peso value of foreign-denominated debt, tightening fiscal space even before new borrowings enter the picture. This vulnerability is deepened by a governance storm that Recto himself acknowledges but does not fully confront. The flood-control scandal, which began as a procurement anomaly, has widened into a larger indictment of the national budget process. Investors have taken notice. Public construction slowed during the third quarter as agencies reexamined procurement flows; foreign funds, already cautious, pulled back further; and the Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) Index reflected the country’s governance anxiety with lackluster performance. The result is a market increasingly inclined to price a governance risk premium into Philippine assets — a premium that low inflation, on its own, cannot offset. His promise of a “better, stronger Philippine economy ahead” arrives at a moment when the administration is eager to reclaim the narrative. Inflation has fallen to multi-year lows, governance initiatives are showcased as proof of reform, and the Palace is intent on signaling renewed economic momentum heading into 2026. On the surface, the optimism is defensible: headline inflation sits at 1.5%, the country maintains a BBB+ rating with a Positive Outlook, and criminal cases stemming from the flood-control scandal have produced visible arrests, asset freezes, and restitutions. Yet the data carefully threaded through this political storyline tells a more complicated truth — one that demands scrutiny as the country’s debt climbs to ₱17.56 trillion and its macroeconomic pillars show signs of stress. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) sharpened this contrast when on Thursday, December 11, it capped 2025 with another 25-basis point policy rate cut, lowering the benchmark borrowing rate to 4.5%. That move, the fifth cut this year and the eighth since August 2024, officially places the economy in an aggressive easing cycle — one enabled by collapsing inflation, but driven by something far less celebratory: weakening growth and rising governance risk. The BSP move acknowledges that overall business sentiment “has continued to decline” due to governance concerns and global uncertainty, and that GDP growth “continued to weaken further.” The third quarter’s 4% expansion, down sharply from earlier quarters, marks the slowest pace since the pandemic-era recovery and reflects the corrosive impact of the flood-control scandal on investor sentiment, public spending execution, and capital formation. The BSP’s decision to ease policy rate, despite a fragile peso, underscores the complexity of the moment. At ₱58.58 to the dollar in October, the peso has depreciated steadily from ₱56.145 a year earlier, eroding purchasing power and inflating foreign-denominated obligations. Every incremental weakening now directly inflates the government’s external-debt burden — already a significant component of the ₱17.56 trillion outstanding stock. This is the structural tension at the heart of today’s macroeconomic landscape: easing monetary policy is meant to stimulate domestic demand, even though it risks amplifying the very debt dynamics that constrain fiscal maneuvering. Meanwhile, the economy’s fundamentals present a mixed picture. Private consumption remains the main growth engine, but real wages have only recently begun to recover; youth unemployment ticked up slightly in October; manufacturing output slowed in four of the last six months; and infrastructure disbursements — supposedly the backbone of the administration’s growth strategy — fell behind schedule due to integrity reviews triggered by corruption investigations. Foreign direct investment inflows, which peaked at US$10.5 billion in 2021, have moderated to around $7.8 billion in the first ten months of 2025, reflecting a cautious external stance toward Philippine political risk. The current account deficit remains sizable at roughly 2.5% of GDP, financed increasingly by short-term portfolio flows rather than long-term investments. Remittances could continue to provide resilience — growing 2.6% year-to-date — but even this stabilizer is insufficient to counterbalance the broader weakening of capital inflows. Recto’s positiveness, while not unfounded, therefore exists alongside structural vulnerabilities that demand careful weighing. Inflation’s benign behavior — below 2% since February — has indeed given the central bank room to maneuver, but the BSP itself warns that the easing cycle is “nearing its end,” and any additional cuts will be strictly data-dependent. It has revised its inflation forecasts modestly upward for 2026 and 2027, signaling early caution. Growth projections, meanwhile, paint a slower path than what the Palace implies: the BSP expects a “gradual” recovery, driven not by organic momentum, but by the lagged effects of monetary easing and improved public spending efficiency. This is not the language of an economy sprinting toward a strong rebound; it is the language of an institution preparing for a long, uneven healing process. The Philippines does have assets: a young demographic profile, resilient remittances, moderating inflation, and a central bank willing to act decisively. Yet the challenge now is credibility: fiscal, institutional, and political. The cumulative 2-percentage-point rate cut since last year may support domestic demand, but unless governance reforms translate into predictable budgeting, transparent procurement, and restored investor trust, monetary stimulus alone will not deliver the “strong comeback” heralded by the administration. The country must grow faster than its debt, restore confidence faster than scandals can erode it, and bolster the peso faster than external shocks can weaken it. Recto’s optimism may indeed prove prophetic — but only if the numbers, not the rhetoric, begin moving in his desired direction. The “better, stronger” economic phase will depend, not on inflation numbers or international ratings, but on the country’s ability to confront the structural risks that soften the foundations beneath Recto’s upbeat narrative. This is where the administration’s narrative becomes difficult to sustain. Recto’s emphasis on the Philippines’ better inflation numbers — a genuine achievement given global price volatility — neither neutralize concerns over the country’s debt trajectory nor calm markets increasingly sensitive to institutional instability. Price stability may support consumption, but it does not address the deeper risks posed by slower output expansion, rising refinancing costs, and a currency that remains vulnerable to both global conditions and local governance shocks. The government’s optimism rests on inflation data, while investors are looking at debt ratios, fiscal credibility, and signals from the political economy. It is no coincidence that Recto’s statement devotes substantial attention to the administration’s anti-corruption drive. The flood-control scandal — which now implicates lawmakers, Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) officials, and contractors — has evolved into a broader examination of how the national budget is crafted, allocated, and potentially manipulated. That the executive secretary finds it necessary to highlight arrests, AMLC asset freezes amounting to ₱13 billion, the auction of ₱38.2 million worth of seized luxury vehicles, and the ₱110 million restitution from a DPWH district engineer, speaks volumes about the scale of reputational damage the scandal has inflicted. Markets do not respond to arrests as they do to institutional reform, but they do react to credibility risk — and the scandal has already tightened scrutiny on the entire ₱6-trillion fiscal cycle. Even public construction, a traditional growth engine, has shown signs of deceleration, as agencies quietly reassess procurement procedures in the wake of the controversy. Foreign funds that had already reduced exposure to Philippine equities and bonds now cite governance uncertainty as a major reason for maintaining underweight positions. In this sense, Recto’s assurances of stronger governance become less a sign of institutional strength and more an admission that the Marcos Jr. administration knows market confidence is fragile and must be aggressively managed. The promise of a “disciplined” ₱6.793-trillion budget for 2026 reinforces this point. Governments do not promise discipline unless they know discipline is in doubt. The budget process — magnified by the controversies of bicameral insertions — has turned into a barometer of political influence rather than economic planning. Investors understand this intuitively, rating agencies model it explicitly, and the peso now reflects it through sensitivity to governance headlines. Recto’s optimism that reforms, tax enforcement recalibrations, and investment promotion efforts will revive growth in 2026 is plausible only if the government can rebuild trust in the fiscal system itself. The macroeconomic risks ahead are neither abstract nor distant. A debt-to-GDP ratio drifting toward 62 to 63% would place the Philippines at the edge of ratings-agency caution. A continued slide of the peso could widen fiscal gaps and further inflate foreign debt obligations. A slowdown in public or private investment — even marginal — could weaken the growth base needed to sustain long-term borrowing. These are not risks that inflation can offset, or issues that can be resolved merely by high-level assurances of a “strong comeback.” Ultimately, the Philippines stands at a critical juncture where credibility has become the economy’s most valuable — and most vulnerable — asset. Recto’s optimism is not misplaced; it is incomplete. The administration’s success will depend, not on inflation numbers or credit ratings, but on whether it can restore confidence in the country’s fiscal architecture, institutional discipline, and governance systems. Until then, markets will continue to price the economy, not on the promise of better days, but on the reality of rising debt, slowing growth, and a political environment still struggling to convince investors that the rules of public finance are stable, predictable, and enforced. – Rappler.com Click here for more Vantage Point articles.
label: True
title: [Vantage Point] As BSP cuts policy rates, PH’s mounting debts weaken optimism

text: This week, on October 28, Tuesday, the peso slid to a historic low of P59.13 per US dollar. To be sure, this is not our first brush with the P59 per US dollar mark. You might recall that we’ve had similar brushes back in September-October 2022, and also November-December 2024. I wrote about it last year. What’s different now is that the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas or BSP seems to be more willing to allow the peso to slide even further, breaching the psychological P60-per-US-dollar barrier. BSP Governor Eli Remolona said that P60 per US dollar “is a possibility.” The BSP added that, “The recent peso depreciation may reflect market concerns over a potential moderation in economic growth due in part to the infrastructure spending controversy, as well as expectations of additional monetary policy easing by the BSP.” You see, even before the flood control controversy, our growth prospects were already dimming. The government had already trimmed its growth targets from 6-8% down to 5.5-6.5%. Reaching 6% growth these days seems like a moonshot. Slower growth is made worse by the flood control scandal. Myriad business groups are desperately asking the administration of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. to credibly solve this mess, because investors here and abroad are fast losing confidence in the Philippines. In a strongly worded statement, a big group of employers and workers’ associations recently called out the feeble investigations and prosecution of the government of people involved in flood control corruption. They said, “Instead of hold departure orders, we are told to be content with immigration lookout bulletins for now. Instead of criminal charges, we are fed daily promises of cases ‘soon to be filed.’ Instead of open transparent hearings, we get closed-door investigations whose direction remains unknown.” Worse, it’s possible that some investors are already moving their capital away from the Philippines to invest elsewhere. The stock market’s capitalization went down by hundreds of billions of pesos in recent weeks. When investors flee, the demand for dollars increases, and this makes the peso weaker. BSP Governor Remolona also remarked that there are now “fewer companies with expansion plans.” In case you missed it, even before this brouhaha, foreign direct investments have been stagnant (rather than growing) in recent years. The peso’s slide could be reversed by a sufficiently strong inflow of dollars. But foreign investors’ perceptions on the Philippine economy are also souring. Jose Manuel “Babe” Romualdez, our ambassador to the US, alleged that at least $100 billion in investments are being put off because of recent political events. The BSP, if it wanted to, can prevent the exchange rate from reaching P60 per US dollar. This was done before by the BSP under the watch of former governor Benjamin Diokno. Back in 2022, he drew a line in the sand and said that the BSP will aggressively prevent a breach. This was done by selling billions of dollars of the BSP’s reserves. Fast-forward to 2025, Governor Remolona seems less inclined to do such a thing. I would tend to agree with him. Shelling out tons of dollars just to avoid P60 per US dollar seems a huge waste of money. It would be better to keep that money to maintain a sufficiently large buffer of international reserves. Just let the exchange rate be determined by supply and demand. Of course, “defending” the peso may seem politically attractive, because it would be a historic first if we reached P60 per US dollar under Marcos’ watch. And not a few people might think that a historically “weak” peso might reflect a similar weakness of the President. But to be honest, I don’t care too much for the terms “weak” or “strong” peso. A “weak” peso, for instance, is actually a good thing for exporters (because our goods and services become more competitive) and dollar-earning OFWs (because the money they send home will translate into more pesos). The bigger concern is that our export industry is not sufficiently diversified to begin with: the biggest chunk of our exports remains to be semiconductors, and we can’t expect to earn a lot more if we don’t export goods which are higher value-added. The fact that the peso is weakening also suggests that remittance growth is not as strong as they used to be (because strong remittance inflows would tend to make the peso stronger rather than weaker). Above anything else, the weaker peso is a sign of weaker confidence in the Philippine economy. And the longer it takes for the Marcos administration to go after (and even jail) the corrupt, the longer it will take for business confidence to recover, and the more capital will want to flee the country. The peso’s fate is in the hands of Marcos himself. – Rappler.com JC Punongbayan, PhD is an assistant professor at the UP School of Economics and the author of False Nostalgia: The Marcos “Golden Age” Myths and How to Debunk Them. In 2024, he received The Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) Award for economics. Follow him on Instagram (@jcpunongbayan).
label: True
title: [In This Economy] Is massive corruption to blame for the historically weak peso?

text: NEW YORK, USA – Big retailers traditionally spend millions on attracting eyeballs for the holiday season. Now, they’re looking to get noticed by something else — AI agents. Most of this holiday season’s projected $253 billion in US online sales will happen through website visits or standard online searches that favor companies that spend big on search engine ads. But chatbots like OpenAI’s ChatGPT or Google’s Gemini have become part of the mix, with shopper-facing tools that can give product descriptions, compare prices, or allow purchases directly within large-language models as US consumers increasingly use AI for advice on the best holiday stocking stuffers. “We’ve seen brands that previously were putting out three or four new blog posts or articles a month, are now trying to do 100 or 200,” said Brian Stempeck, chief executive at generative engine optimization platform Evertune.ai, which works with clients to make their websites discoverable by large language models. The company charges “around $3,000” per month to its clients, which include apparel and shoe companies, for its services, Stempeck said. Traditionally, retailers based their Google and Meta ad placements on phrases that users searched for or links they previously clicked. Without the ability to advertise in the largest generative AI tools, companies are trying new methods, like posting more frequently on branded blogs or writing about their products on Reddit. Big retailers are building websites that cannot be seen by shoppers, intended to be read solely by AI scrapers, automated data extraction tools that scour the internet for information. The scrapers then feed information to platforms like ChatGPT and Gemini, which then offer suggestions on gifts, apparel and other holiday merchandise. Traffic to retail websites from generative AI platforms is currently still a fraction of overall activity. ChatGPT referrals to Amazon, Walmart and eBay in October accounted for less than 1% of each site’s overall traffic, according to data firm Sensor Tower. EBay said while traffic from AI sources is a small percentage of overall traffic, shoppers finding its links through agentic AI come to the online marketplace with high intent. Walmart did not respond to a request for comment. But retailers clearly see an opportunity. Bed linen company Brooklinen is paying social media influencers to talk about its bath towels and comforters on platforms like Facebook, YouTube, and TikTok, Brooklinen Chief Operating Officer Rachel Levy said. AI scrapers pull information from the text of product reviews and audio transcripts on these posts. Brooklinen has also submitted its $199 comforter for awards from publications like the New York Times’ Wirecutter to boost its chances of appearing in AI agent responses. Currently, traffic from agentic AI sources is “super small,” she said, because Gen Z, the biggest adopter of tools like ChatGPT, has less buying power than older generations. Miami-based hair care company R+Co is buying ads on Amazon’s voice assistant Alexa based on the questions that customers are asking its Rufus agent, R+Co President Dan Langer said. Google recently introduced features that help shoppers use AI to track prices and buy goods, a task that can only happen if retailers share product details through the tech giant’s merchant center directly or when their products are easily found by its scrapers. Its AI mode and Gemini chatbot consider numerous factors, such as store locations or retailer quality when referring links to users, said Lilian Rincon, vice president of product for Google Shopping. Google is testing ads in AI Mode currently in the U.S., but not the Gemini app, the company said. Existing Shopping and Performance Max ad product campaigns are eligible to show up in AI mode through the testing, the company said. ChatGPT on Monday released additional shopping features to help people with product comparisons and search for “lookalikes” merchandise. Amazon CEO Andy Jassy said on the company’s October earnings call that shoppers who use Rufus are 60% more likely to buy products. Among large retailers, Walmart and Target both recently announced plans for apps to allow people to shop directly with chatbots. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: As AI reshapes shopping, US retailers try to change how they’re seen online

text: MANILA, Philippines – President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. is reviewing calls to oust Government Service Insurance System (GSIS) President and General Manager Jose Arnulfo “Wick” Veloso over alleged gross mismanagement of government workers’ pension fund, Malacañang said. Presidential Communications Office (PCO) Undersecretary Claire Castro said in a briefing on Monday, October 20, that Marcos expected agency heads to demonstrate proper leadership and would not hesitate to act on the controversies surrounding the GSIS chief. “Hindi naman po agad-agad nabibigla dahil kung mayroon pong mga reklamo sa ngayon, dapat po itong inaaral nang masinsinan (The President can’t just act on these complaints on a whim because these should be thoroughly reviewed),” Castro said. Malacañang’s remarks come after past and present GSIS officials urged Veloso to resign for the alleged mismanagement of the social security fund for GSIS members, which supposedly resulted in P8.8 billion in investment losses. According to the group’s letter to Veloso dated October 14, Veloso has exhibited a pattern of actions that were seemingly designed to bypass the proper governance of the investment fund. This includes splitting investment transactions to circumvent the need for the GSIS Board’s approval. “Your actions have fundamentally undermined the integrity and collegiality of the Board. Rather than engaging in professional discourse, you have resorted to fabricating issues and weaponizing administrative procedures to retaliate against members exercising their fiduciary duty of oversight,” they wrote. The six individuals, including four incumbent members of the GSIS Board, flagged investments in companies such as Eusebio Tanco’s DigiPlus Interactive Corporation, Enrique Razon’s Bloomberry Resorts Corporation, and Alternergy Holdings Corporation. The Ombudsman previously placed Veloso under preventive suspension over the P1.45-billion investment into Alternergy, but this was lifted in September. Veloso has since vowed to dispose of GSIS’ stake in DigiPlus and Alternergy once the market improves. As of 1:46 pm on Monday trade, Alternergy share prices were flat at P0.88 apiece, while DigiPlus shares were 0.22% higher at P23 apiece. In a statement on Friday, October 17, Veloso said he will not step down as he serves at the pleasure of the President. He insisted that claims over investment losses were baseless and that the state workers’ pension fund has outperformed its targets for the year. “As of August 2025, GSIS’s total assets have climbed to P1.92 trillion, net income has reached P100.02 billion, and total income stands at P231.06 billion. These results clearly demonstrate that, despite market headwinds, GSIS remains financially strong, resilient, and highly profitable,” Veloso wrote. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Marcos reviewing calls to sack GSIS chief Veloso

text: CEBU, Philippines – Just weeks after a 6.9-magnitude earthquake and Typhoon Tino (Kalmaegi) devastated communities across Cebu province, over 400 business process outsourcing (BPO) workers were notified they would be placed on floating status, a temporary layoff with no pay and no option to seek similar work for up to six months. The notice from Wipro Cebu arrived as many were still repairing damaged homes and dealing with disrupted utilities, compounding the strain of the back-to-back disasters. BPO Industry Employees’ Network (BIEN)-Cebu chairperson Kyle Enero told Rappler that the layoffs have further heightened employees’ anxieties, particularly among long-serving workers. “Lisod sa ilaha jud,” said Enero. “Klaro ang tumong sa paglay-off sa ilaha: pagputol sa length of service nga mapugos og resign ang mga ahente aron mas gamay ilahang mahatag nga bayad ug benepisyo. Sa ingon ani nga pamaagi, gipakita sa kumpanya nga pagpasiguro sa dakong ginansya gihapon ang prayoridad.” (It is really difficult for them. The purpose of the layoff is clear: to cut the length-of-service of employees, forcing agents to resign so the company can provide lower pay and benefits. This way, the company shows that securing large profits remains its top priority.) This adds to ongoing labor and safety concerns in Cebu City’s BPO sector, where employees were reportedly forced to work during the September 30 earthquake despite building damage, with some threatened for opting to evacuate and others sent back to production floors without proper safety checks. Several of the affected Wipro Cebu employees have been with the company for six years or more, and many of them found the layoff notice completely unexpected. Enero told Rappler that for long-serving workers, the announcement “felt like a form of betrayal after years of service.” Workers also questioned Wipro’s claim that the layoffs were due to performance issues since some of the affected employees are among the company’s top performers, making the decision appear arbitrary. “They say it’s really unfair because the reason given for selecting them for the layoff was their performance, even though performance isn’t actually an issue, as some top performers were also included,” said Enero in Cebuano. He recounted the case of a worker who was initially placed on floating status arbitrarily and later subjected to a performance improvement plan for allegedly poor performance, despite already being on floating status at the time. He added that the same employee has now been included in Wipro’s latest round of floating layoffs. “This only exposes that the BPO industry practice of placing agents on floating status, combined with a high attrition rate, puts workers in a precarious situation where their livelihood is directly affected, often forcing them to leave the company — not by choice, but due to circumstances — which essentially amounts to constructive dismissal,” said Enero. He added that during his conversations with workers, their main concern was their benefits and fair compensation, particularly as many are still recovering from the recent typhoon and earthquake. Enero explained that the floating status system is a new form of cost-cutting in the BPO industry, designed to pressure employees to resign so companies can avoid paying benefits that increase with length of service. “While floating status is legal, it does not make it moral or ethical,” he said. Rappler has reached out to Wipro Cebu for comment. This story will be updated once we get a response. In a statement, BIEN-Cebu condemned Wipro’s recent actions, describing the placement of over 400 employees on floating status as an attack on workers’ rights. “While Wipro management has initiated a reprofiling process, they remain deaf to workers’ requests for separation pay and the option to exit the company,” the network said. BIEN-Cebu also urged the Wipro management to grant severance pay to employees placed on floating status, honor requests from workers who wish to be reprofiled to other roles, and show genuine compassion for those still recovering from recent calamities. Enero recently filed a request for dialogue with the Department of Labor and Employment-Regional Office VII (DOLE-VII) to discuss updates on inspections following the September 30 earthquake and address the numerous cases of temporary layoffs in the BPO sector. – Rappler.com Marjuice Destinado is a senior political science student at Cebu Normal University (CNU) and an alumna of the Aries Rufo Journalism Fellowship of Rappler for 2025.
label: True
title: After back-to-back disasters, 400 Cebu BPO workers face job uncertainty

text: LONDON, United Kingdom – Global investors managing over $3 trillion in assets called on governments on Monday, October 20, to stop and reverse deforestation and ecosystem degradation by 2030, in a statement signed ahead of a United Nations climate conference in Brazil next month. Around 30 institutional investors including Swiss private bank Pictet Group and Nordic investor DNB Asset Management have so far signed up to the Belém Investor Statement on Rainforests, which is open until November 1. A report last week found the world is falling far short of the goal of stopping deforestation, with losses of 8.1 million hectares (20 million acres) of forest — an area about the size of England — in 2024 alone, largely driven by agricultural expansion and forest fires. “As investors, we are increasingly concerned about the material financial risks that tropical deforestation and nature loss pose to our portfolios,” the statement said. The investors emphasized the need for policies that deliver legal, regulatory, and financial certainty to help protect the forests and safeguard economic stability, said Jan Erik Saugestad, chief executive officer at Nordic firm Storebrand Asset Management. “Deforestation undermines the natural systems that global markets rely on — from climate regulation to food and water security.” Earlier this year, the European Union delayed launching its anti-deforestation law by a year after facing opposition from industry and trade partners such as Brazil, Indonesia, and the United States, who say complying with the rules would be costly and hurt their exports to Europe. The role of climate skeptic US President Donald Trump in rolling back support for global environmental efforts was also hampering action, said Ingrid Tungen, head of deforestation-free markets at Rainforest Foundation Norway. “I think Trump has made it more difficult for investors and managers to take climate and biodiversity into account in such a volatile market,” she said. “All the investors that we are talking to think there is a huge risk for us not taking diversification and climate change into consideration in the long term, and not just for their own morals, but because that will harm the markets directly and their profits directly.” – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Investors managing $3 trillion in assets urge countries to stop deforestation

text: TOKYO, Japan – Japan’s Asahi Group on Thursday, November 27, said the personal details of 1.52 million customers may have been leaked in a September cyberattack. The beverage maker said the September 29 cyberattack forced it to suspend operations including order processing, shipping and call-center functions. Asahi said it consequently delayed the release of its July-September earnings results scheduled for November 12 to more than 50 days after the end of the quarter. “We can’t avoid forecasting a deterioration in our results but our mid-to-long-term management plan is unchanged,” CEO Atsushi Katsuki said at a press briefing. The disruption saw restaurants, bars and stores in Japan run low on Asahi beer —including best-selling “Super Dry” brand — and other drinks. Asahi resumed production at six domestic factories the week following the attack. Ransomware group Qilin on October 9 claimed to have orchestrated the attack. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Asahi Group says personal details of 1.5 million customers may have been leaked in cyberattack

text: MANILA, Philippines – Jollibee Foods Corporation (JFC) is creating a standalone international company in preparation for a possible listing on a United States securities exchange by 2027, the fastfood giant announced on Tuesday, January 6. In a disclosure to the Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE), JFC said its international operations and business will be separated from its Philippine counterpart through the establishment of Jollibee Foods Corporation International (JFCI). This new firm will encapsulate all operations and businesses outside of the Philippines. JFC’s Philippine operations, meanwhile, will remain listed on the local bourse. The company explained that the spinoff will allow both entities to sharpen their strategic focus. “Built on a capital-light model with significant whitespace for expansion, it is positioned to operate in markets that support companies pursuing international scale, innovation, and long-term global growth,” the fastfood giant owned by Tony Tan Caktiong said. JFC added that it is already working on establishing the structure, process, and timing for the separation of the two business units and JFCI’s potential international listing. This may include any restructuring and asset transfers. Jollibee Group’s global president and chief executive officer Ernesto Tanmantiong said the spin-off and its potential US listing will demonstrate the firm’s strength on the global change. “As a proudly homegrown Philippine company, we carry our heritage and express our national pride into this next chapter of our journey. Our move toward an international listing demonstrates the strength of the Jollibee Group, a company with Filipino roots competing on the world stage,” he wrote in a statement. According to Rappler’s stock market analyst Den Somera, the spin-off will unlock values for JFC that the Philippine market cannot due to its current limitations. However, it remains unclear how the assets will be split between the two firms. Nonetheless, he said “the plan is beneficial to JFC price in the short term.” Unicapital equity research analyst Jeri Alfonso likened JFC’s spinoff to San Miguel Brewery’s (SMB) split from the main San Miguel Corporation (SMC) conglomerate in 2007. With the split, SMB gave investors the option to put their money in San Miguel’s brewery business, and provide the firm with more focused management. “After the deal, JFC on the PSE will be a pure domestic play, making it more comparable to local peers like Max’s Group (MAXS) and Shakey’s (PIZZA),” Alfonso told Rappler in a Viber message. While JFC’s share price is expected to drop due to the split, Alfonso believes the price will eventually adjust accordingly to fairly compensate existing investors. “In addition to this, bear in mind JFC shareholders will get JFCI shares as a property dividend,” she pointed out. According to JFC’s annual report, its international business units include the following: Meanwhile, its Philippine business units include Jollibee Philippines, Mang Inasal, Greenwich, and Red Ribbon. It also includes its foreign franchised brands such as Burger King, Panda Express, Yoshinoya, and Tiong Bahru Bakery. JFC posted a net income of just over P9 billion in the first nine months of 2025, with system-wide sales (SWS) of the Philippine business growing 5.5% in the third quarter. Its international business’ SWS also jumped 32.4% in the January-September 2025 period thanks to Compose Coffee and the strong performance of Jollibee’s international markets. During the first nine months of 2025, Compose Coffee’s SWS surged 540.9% and CBTL’s revenues also grew 13.9%. Milksha, which JFC acquired in 2025, saw its SWS grow 5.9%, while Tim Ho Wan‘s system-wide sales contracted by 20.2%. JFC share prices surged 14.5% to P210 apiece on Monday trade. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: What’s the impact of Jollibee’s planned spinoff and US listing of its int’l business?

text: MANILA, Philippines – The global think tank Tony Blair Institute on Thursday, July 24, released a report outlining how government strategies on leveraging AI technology for the economy should focus on a human-centric “augmented” approach rather than allowing for the outright automation of tasks. The paper recalls how previous industrial revolutions such as mechanization in the 18th century led to physical labor being superseded by machines — a shift that governments then responded to by prioritizing education that would open opportunities for cognitive work. Now, that cognitive work is at the risk of being replaced by generative AI, which has shown the capacity to process information and data, and produce something out of it such as computer code, a written analysis, or a new image or video. The institute proposes what it calls “augmented intelligence,” an approach that seeks to empower the worker to use AI as a tool, and allow themselves to perform “higher-order tasks.” “By embedding machine-generated insights into workflows, this approach enables a broader segment of the workforce – particularly those in practical, hands-on roles — to perform higher-order tasks such as data interpretation, situational judgement and adaptive decision-making to make roles more productive, meaningful and futureproofed,” the institute says. Examples include care assistants using AI to monitor their patient’s wellbeing, electrical technicians using AI-enabled drones and diagnostics to make repairs, or paramedics using AI to provide timely, critical insights. “In short, augmented intelligence is about creating new kinds of jobs that combine human empathy, judgement and adaptability with the power of AI,” it says. Human empathy, judgement, and adaptability, among other humanistic traits, appear to remain as part of a person’s domain and not that of an AI system’s at least for now. Just as humans found a way to specialize in cognitive work as mechanical tools took over physical labor in the past, the challenge now, as the paper shows, is to find the tasks that only a human is able to achieve. The study looks at 3 countries — Singapore, Vietnam, and the Phlippines — and presents an overview of the challenges that each faces in adopting the “augmented intelligence” approach. In the Philippines, the paper provides 4 examples how this approach might look like in several industries: How does the country get there? The report notes several government initiatives that point to a development vision that has AI squarely in its sights. Under the Philippine Development Plan 2023-2028, the National AI Strategy Roadmap 2.0, and Philippine Skills Framework, AI and digitalization are looked at as major components in fostering economic growth, job creation, and poverty reduction. The AI roadmap presents a plan for integrating AI into key industries, while the skills framework seeks to align educational outcomes with the AI-related jobs of the future. The Department of Education also established The Education Center for AI Research in February 2025 while the National Innovation Council, directly under the President, established an AI thinktank in March 2025 that seeks to inform AI policies and improve the country’s global competitiveness. All of these initiatives are meant to steer the populace to an AI-enabled economy wherein generative AI is expected to contribute P2.8 trillion by 2030, the report says. Will the country get there? The study outlines a few major hurdles. First of all, connectivity remains an issue, especially when one compares connectivity in the cities versus the provinces. It says that policies should “address the urban-rural digital divide by expanding access to affordable digital infrastructure, such as connectivity, and training programs.​” The government needs to come in to help smaller businesses, and industries in the province to address a digital gap that slows down AI adoption. Increasing funding for AI research as well as incentivizing the development of homegrown digital solutions are seen as necessary pillars to help the country reach its AI goals. Upskilling, with the proposed “augmented intelligence” approach will also be urgently needed as the International Monetary Fund expects that 4 out of 10 jobs in the Philippines will be affected by AI. Cybersecurity is a part of the picture as well, as data breaches may erode the trust people have in digital systems. “Stakeholders emphasized the need for a shift towards more proactive policies in which governments do not merely mitigate risks, but actively shape AI adoption to create economic and social value. This shift will include fostering public-private partnerships, setting clear regulatory frameworks, and incentivizing local innovation ecosystems and entities to flourish,” the study says. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Gov’t-led AI plans underway but infrastructure, skills need addressing – think tank

text: MANILA, Philippines – The Social Security System (SSS) marked 2025 with a landmark three-year pension reform that will increase benefits without increasing contribution rates. Starting September 1, the state pension fund raised retirement and disability pensions by 10%, while death and survivor pensions will be increased by 5%. SSS president and Chief Executive Officer Robert Joseph Montes De Claro said the state pension fund will carry out the second tranche of pension hikes on September 1, 2026. The final wave of pension hikes will take effect in September 2027. By the end of the three-year program, benefits for retirement and disability pensioners will have increased by 33% while death and survivor pensioners’ benefits are estimated to grow 16%. This will cover over 3.8 million SSS pensioners, including 2.6 million retirement or disability pensioners and 1.2 million survivor pensioners. Apart from pension increases, the SSS also aims to launch a micro loan program in early 2026. Its emergency loan program with a 7% interest rate from the original 10% will also be available until December 2026 or until the state of national calamity is lifted. De Claro earlier said the pension hike will shorten its fund life to 2049 from 2053. But he is confident that this will be offset by stronger cash flows from previous contribution increases and enhanced collection efforts. “Our actuarial team confirms that the fund remains financially sound. We are committed to restoring fund life back to 2053 through coverage expansion and improved collection efficiency,” he said. The SSS in January implemented a 1% contribution hike to 15% from 14% as part of a rate hike that started in 2019. As of September 2024, the SSS has nearly P55 billion in assets and has P11.3 billion in reserves for the future payment of employee compensation claims. De Claro previously said they expect SSS’ net income growth to slow down in 2025 as the fund implements the three-year pension hike. However, he remains optimistic that the pension fund will make at least P100 billion. The SSS made a P90.2 billion profit in 2024, with earnings from the fund’s investments contributing more than half of its bottomline. The SSS currently has around P500 billion invested in long-term government securities while the remaining 45% of the fund’s portfolio is invested in the capital market and real estate. (READ: SSS invests P500 million in Century Properties) – Rappler.com
label: True
title: What you need to know about SSS’ 3-year pension hike

text: In my last article, I wrote about the just-concluded initial public offering (IPO) of Maynilad Water Services Incorporated, which was listed last Friday, November 7, 2025, under the trading symbol of “MYNLD.” In the article, I mentioned that with the exception of Joel De la Peña, market strategist and chief trader of H.E. Bennett Securities Incorporated, who was dead sure that MYNLD would tank even on listing day, the rest of the traders I talked to were optimistic, albeit cautious. To what I see in last Friday’s listing, MYNLD may be in for a difficult ride like what the market has been in general: MYNLD opened at its IPO offer price of P15 per share that also served as its session high; it traded lower to P14.98 a piece that also served as its session’s low and closing price for the day. Correspondingly, MYNLD was down P0.020 or 0.13% with a total volume for the day of about 100.81 million shares on a total value turnover of approximately P1.51 billion. This happened on the back of a selling pressure on the issue itself. To what I was told, one of the underwriters was behind the sell off. Nevertheless, it may be too early yet to say whether MYNLD will fall in the coming days as De la Peña is anticipating. MYNLD only fell one fluctuation lower throughout the trading session. On second thought, considering that MYNLD never had the chance to go up any higher than its opening price all throughout the trading session, it’s very possible that De la Peña may just get his wishes to come true. This is also supported by one almost forgotten maxim in the market, which says that a market’s one-year performance is sometimes already known by the results of its trading performance from its first month of trading for the year. Likewise, MYNLD’s initial trading performance may just be indicative enough of where the market is headed to. Remember, last Friday’s trading results: the market tanked again lower. This time, it closed at its three-year low of 5,759.37, reminiscent of its trading close on October 3, 2022. From what it has been doing all these months up to its trading results last Friday, the technical picture of the market can be described as: “bearish, facing significant pressure, and trading at historically low valuations.” In comparison to its regional and international peers, the market is now one of the world’s worst-performing markets. Out of this performance, around 18% or more of the market’s value has been lost since then. The general P/E ratio of the Philippine Stock Exchange Index’s (PSEi) composite stocks has now also gone down to as low as 8.2x. In retrospect, this is lower than the market’s P/E multiple during the March 2020 COVID-19 pandemic. Based on historical averages, the market can be described as “significantly undervalued.” The market’s continuing fall has been attributed to the trading tack of foreign investors who have been described as “aggressively cashing out.” Foreign investors have been net sellers for the year until last Friday. The general pessimism stems from a combination of local and global factors. Foremost to local and foreign investors’ concern is the country’s slowing economic growth. As corroborated in last Friday announcement, the country’s gross domestic product (GDP) slowed down in the 3rd quarter. GDP only grew by 4%. There are three major factors that are blamed for the market’s continued weakness and the country’s weak GDP growth. The first is about the escalating corruption scandal on public funds used in the government’s flood control program. The second is about the government’s weak spending or underspending activity to spur the economy. The third is about the structural issues confronting the market. The flood control corruption scandal has greatly angered the general public just as it has significantly eroded investors’ confidence and dampened bullish sentiments. Aside from the sporadic pockets of public rallies that are being held since the corruption scandal was exposed, a grand protest-rally similar to the historic EDSA People Power movement is being planned to be held on November 30. What it may come to as a result may also have a serious impact on the future political landscape, especially on the alignments among the political players. As to the government’s public spending program to spur economic growth, the government is reportedly lagging behind, especially on its educational and social safety nets, targeted spending to boost agriculture, climate resilience, and digital connectivity, in addition to its “Build Better More” infrastructure program. The government is called on to move faster on these areas of concerns. On its structural issues, the market continues to face medium- to long-term challenges, particularly to its liquidity and trading volume, which can be described as poor and thin compared to its regional peers. Added to that, the market lacks sectoral diversity. At present, the index is heavily concentrated in financials and industrials. Likewise, fewer companies are opting to go public due to the higher costs and stringent rules to get listed. Listed firms have, as well, historically underperformed — like what may just happen again to MYNLD despite being a great issue to lock in one’s investible fund. Senator Imee Marcos recently gave a simple solution to the market’s structural issues. At first, it appeared almost ridiculous but come to think of it, her suggestion has some sense of logic: it’s about time the bourse’s president, Ramon Monzon, is replaced. To her, Monzon has been there for too long for during his watch, the market has gone through the full cycle of trading from doom-to-boom and then from boom-to-doom seemingly oblivious — as in unaffected or unmitigated — by his presence. She then simply concludes that Monzon had his time, and the board of the bourse should now put new blood in the leadership helm. With regard to investors’ outlook, like any perspective, I believe that this will change eventually for the better — although not that soon, maybe. At the moment, many investors are taking a “risk-off” or “defensive positioning” stance. The market is definitely now out of favor: the local economy’s status, along with the political issues and the sporadic cases of social unrest, have not been helpful. The weakening of our currency against the US dollar to historic lows has likewise created selling pressures in the market. Together with concerns over a global economic slowdown and the not-so-impressive performance of key sectors like our electronics exports, the market has become that soft, and investors’ confidence has gone low. However, despite the overall market weakness, certain sectors continue to show some resilience and potential. Among these are the financial companies. The financials index has shown positive movements. The major banks have shown strong balance sheets supported by relatively high-interest-rate margins. Next is the mining and oil sector. It is also showing some promise: this sector has exhibited significant gains over time, driven by increasing commodity price trends and local policy developments. Among these government policies include the lifting of the moratorium on new mining permits, lifting the ban on open-pit mining, and promoting transparency through the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI). The EITI is a global standard for the open and accountable management of oil, gas, and mineral resources. It aims to improve governance in the extractive sector by requiring governments and companies to disclose information on contracts, production, revenues, and beneficial ownership. This disclosure helps to curb corruption, informed public debate, and promote reforms. The other supports arising from the government’s recent policies include financial incentives like tax exemptions on imported equipment for offshore oil and gas operations and a program to manage mineral reservations. The government has also started to focus on environmental and sustainability reforms to encourage responsible development and secure a place in global mineral supply chains.
