Meanwhile, underemployment also eased to 10.4% or 5.11 million Filipinos from 12% or 5.81 million underemployed Filipinos recorded in October 2025. National Statistician Dennis Mapa said the public administration and defense sector and the education sector added the most jobs year-on-year, employing around 185,000 and 176,000 more workers, respectively. But the accommodation and food services sector as well as the wholesale and retail trade sector shed the most jobs as the economy grappled with the impact of Typhoon Tino (Kalmaegi) and Super Typhoon Uwan (Fung-wong) in November. Mapa said restaurants (-191,000), short-term accommodations (-76,000), and event catering (-23,000) shed the most jobs. “Ang reading namin is that because of these [tropical cyclones], nagkaroon ng slowdown in economic activities related to tourism, doon sa accommodation services at of course, ‘yung retail trade,” he explained. (Our reading is that there was a slowdown in economic activities related to tourism because of these tropical cyclones, particularly in accommodation services and of course, retail trade.) The Department of Economy, Planning, and Development (DEPDev) also estimated that Tino and Uwan affected some 873,000 workers. Mapa further noted that the agriculture and forestry sector has lost 517,000 jobs since October. “Employment in the agricultural sector has always been sensitive to weather conditions,” he said in Filipino. Despite disruptions in the construction sector due to the flood control scandal, Mapa said they did not see a correlation between the ongoing corruption probe and job losses. In fact, the construction sector added around 143,000 jobs between October and November. To minimize business disruptions, DEPDev Secretary Arsenio Balisacan said the government will support businesses in crafting continuity and resiliency plans. He added that DEPDev is pushing for the full implementation of the Philippine Innovation Act to help develop more entrepreneurs and boost job demand. The country’s chief economist also said the government is prioritizing investments in skills development and lifelong learning to empower workers and allow them to weather economic shocks. Data from online job portal Jobstreet by SEEK found that candidates from call centers and customer service were the most active jobseekers on the platform, but administrative and office support roles were the most in-demand roles being recruited for. Meanwhile, jobseekers were on the lookout for jobs in engineering and education. “Strengthening workforce competitiveness is one of the key elements to attract investments that generate quality jobs,” Balisacan said. – with reports from Arriane dela Cruz/Rappler.com Arriane dela Cruz is a Rappler intern. Learn more about Rappler’s internship program here.
label: True
title: Unemployment eases to 4.4% in November 2025 despite Tino, Uwan’s impact on tourism

text: United States President Donald Trump and his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping have wrapped up a meeting in South Korea with a deal to keep Chinese rare earth exports flowing. Here are some basic facts about these obscure elements making headlines around the world: Rare earths are a group of 17 elements including 15 silvery-white metals called lanthanides, or lanthanoids, plus scandium and yttrium. Rare earths or the magnets which they are sometimes made into can be found in small but important quantities in everything from iPhones and washing machines to the F35 fighter jet. They are also used in electric vehicles (EVs), medical equipment, oil refining, and other military applications such as missiles and radar systems. Without them, supply chains quickly grind to a halt. Automakers were forced to paused some production earlier this year after Chinese export controls caused shortages. They are not rare in the sense that they are uncommon; some are more common than lead, for example. But they tend to be spread thin around the Earth’s crust in small quantities and mixed together or with other minerals, so larger deposits are difficult to find and costly to extract. While US scientists helped developed a process to separate and refine rare earths in the 1950s, China since the 1980s has come to dominate the industry thanks to lower costs, laxer environmental standards, and decades of government support. China accounts for about 60% of global mine production and 90% or more of refined production and rare earth magnet output. Projects are underway across the US, Europe, and Australia to build an alternative supply chain but it will take years to produce meaningful quantities. In the meantime, China is restricting exports of an increasing number of the elements and the equipment needed to mine and refine them. In their periodic table order, they are: scandium, yttrium, lanthanum, cerium, praseodymium, neodymium, promethium, samarium, europium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, holmium, erbium, thulium, ytterbium, and lutetium. Processing rare earths often involves the use of solvents, which can produce toxic waste that pollutes the soil, water, and atmosphere. More environmentally friendly technologies are being developed, but they are not yet widely used. Certain types of rare earth ores also contain radioactive thorium or uranium, which is often removed using acid. For this reason, development of the sector faces health and environmental regulatory hurdles. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: FAST FACTS: What are rare earths and why are they so important?

text: “My Queen, you are the fairest of them all.” This was the answer of the magic mirror every time the reigning queen asked this iconic question in the romanticized children’s literature of the Brothers Grimm, and popularized by the Disney movie, Snow White. But, like in the said fairy tale, comes a chilling turn: a new beauty has come of age and emerged to challenge the beauty of the reigning queen. Lifting the plot of Snow White into our stock market story book, the contest for “who is the fairest one of all” is now drawn between two identical investment beauties — that of the reigning listed water utility company and of the new beauty that is soon to debut in the same trading board. The old beauty is Manila Water Company Incorporated (MWC) which was listed in March 2005. The new beauty is no other than Maynilad Water Services Incorporated whose initial public offering (IPO) went underway last October 23 and ended yesterday, October 29, 2025, with its listing date scheduled on November 7, 2025 on the main board of the bourse under the trading symbol of “MYNLD.” The public equity offering involved the sale of 1.935 billion primary common shares and 0.354 billion secondary common shares held by the selling shareholder, Maynilad Water Holding Company Incorporated, for a total of about 2.289 billion shares. Out of the total offered shares of 2.289 billion shares, 0.628 billion or to be more exact 628,656,600 shares, were allotted to meet overhang demand broken down as follows: preferential offer of 24,904,800 primary common shares, an overallotment option of up to 249,047,600 primary common shares, and an upsize option of up to 354,704,200 secondary common shares. At the offer price of P15 per share, the total amount of the public offering (inclusive of the demand overhang options) is equivalent to P34.335 billion — the largest for 2025. The public offering has attracted support from major institutional domestic and international investors with the International Finance Corporation (IFC) and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) as lead cornerstone investors. As of this writing, the upsize option for secondary shares was fully exercised by both financial institutions. The entry of cornerstone investors is a significant development: it serves as a solid vote of confidence that the investment is credible and viable; their presence also serves to ensure a more stable market performance for the issue as cornerstone investors typically agree to a lock-up period where they cannot sell their shares immediately. Not to mention, a stabilization fund is also ready to prop up MYNLD’s market performance upon listing. The net proceeds from the public offering will be used largely for capital expenditures requirements and to some extent for general corporate purposes of the company. MYNLD is the water and wastewater services provider for the West Zone of the greater Metro Manila area. This covers the cities of Manila excluding the districts of Santa Ana and San Andres, Caloocan, Las Piñas, Malabon, Muntinlupa, Navotas, Pasay, and Parañaque except barangay of San Martin de Porres. It also covers three cities of Cavite province particularly Cavite City, Bacoor, and Imus and the municipalities of Kawit, Noveleta, and Rosario. MYNLD is the largest water concessionaire by active connections not only in the Philippines but the whole of Southeast Asia. As of June 30, 2025, the West Zone has a covered area of 540 square kilometers (sq. km) with a population of approximately 10.5 million people. It has 1.56 million billed connections of domestic and non-domestic customers, covering 94.8% of the West Zone’s population. Its concession agreement was granted in 1997 and was recently extended up to January 2047. MWC services the East Zone covering 1,400 sq. km of land area, which includes 24 cities and municipalities in Metro Manila and the province of Rizal. Covered in its service area are parts of the cities of Makati, Manila, and Quezon City, and the entire of Mandaluyong, Marikina, and Pateros. In Rizal, the company serves the city of Antipolo and districts of San Mateo and Angono. It currently services about 7.8 million people with 1.11 million billed connections as of the end of June 2025. Its concession agreement was also recently extended up to January 2047. (READ: Public interest, private hands: How Manila Water, Maynilad got the deal) In 2024, MWC reported P36.6 billion in service revenues while MYNLD reported a slightly lower service revenues of P33.5 billion. Both companies experienced revenue growth driven by factors such as implemented tariff adjustments and recovery of consumption in their respective service areas. However, MYNLD yielded a greater net income of P12.78 billion compared to MWC’s P10.97 billion due to its lighter debt portfolio. MYNLD’s cost of debt is reported to be “50bps lower” compared to that of MWC. For the first half of 2025, MYNLD reported a total revenue of P18.35 billion while MWC reported a P19.99-billion total revenue based on a respective average tariff of P68.2 P/cu.m. and P80.4 P/cu.m. Earnings before interest charges, taxes, depreciation and amortization or EBITDA was P12.74 billion (69.0% margin) for MYNLD and P14.58 billion (73.0% margin) for MWC, ending with a respective net income (NI) of P7.47 billion and P7.96 billion. With the reported net income, MYNLD drew a return on equity (ROE) of 10.0% and 21.0% for MWC. Estimated earnings per share (EPS) for MYNLD is P1.33 and P1.48 for MWC. NRW for MYNLD is 35.3% and 14.4% for MWC. NRW stands for Non-Revenue Water: it’s the water that has been treated and produced but is not billed to customers. It also includes all water lost due to leaks, illegal connections, meter errors, and other forms of theft or unaccounted-for usage. Reducing NRW is crucial for water utilities; it helps improve financial performance, reduce water wastage, and increase efficiency. Market response to the issue is reportedly good — especially from institutional investors. It’s said to be two times (2x) oversubscribed. Demand from “local small investors” (LSI), however, is patently almost absent. This is how metaphoric was the reaction of stockbroker Rene de los Reyes of Abacus Securities Corporation of the Abacus Capital & Investment Corporation group when given the choice to select between the two beauties: “At P15.00 a piece, Maynilad would be trading at 8.8x EV/EBITDA (EV stands for Enterprise Value). Applying that to MWC, its price per should be P49.78. The upside is very good, so I load up on MWC, and ignored MYNLD.” After buying a load, he said again: “I read from another review that MYNLD has a superior dividend yield; it’s 6.4% vs. 5.4% in favor of MYNLD. So, I have to beg even for some shares.” But just then, he was hit again by another bothering news: MYNLD’s dividend yield was not explicitly promised, but a forward-looking impression. In this connection, De Los Reyes had this to say to investors: Don’t get affected by what you read or hear. Stay focused on your main reason why you are investing in the stock issue. In the end, though, he concedes that MYNLD is a good dividend investment play. Jofer Gaite, president and chief trader of Westlink Global Equities Incorporated, totally agrees that MYNLD is a dividend play, all aspects considered. This is also the conclusion of his friend and former colleague Julian Tarrobago who is now on his own as founder and CEO of From Red to Green Investments — describing as well MYNLD as a boring investment with its anticipated stable market performance owing to its non-erratic and predictable revenue stream and cashflow. Andro Leo I. Beltran, vice president, First Metro Sec of the Metrobank Group had this to say: Due to the plans and programs of MYNLD, it can be considered as a core stock in your investment portfolio for the medium to long term. Also, MYNLD has a more superior dividend play vis-à-vis MWC. If it comes to a choice between the two, one’s overall growth and risk objectives should be used as determining factors. For Joel de la Peña, market strategist and chief trader of H.E. Bennett Securities Incorporated, while he is also interested in the issue, he finds MYNLD worth buying at a lower price than its offer price of P15 per share. This is the reason why he is not personally subscribing at the moment because he thinks — like most IPOs in the last 10 years or so — they tank upon listing, with most of them unable to go back even in their IPO offer price. Joey Roxas, president of Eagle Equities Incorporated, also agrees that MYNLD is a “Buy” and prefers it against MWC with its demonstrated operating ability even amidst historical challenges, plus the possibility that it can acquire PrimeWater from Manny Villar. He also begs to disagree with De La Peña that MYNLD will tank upon listing, citing the successful price stabilization strategies employed by present underwriters. (Rappler Investigates: Woeful PrimeWater) Wishing to be identified only as “M” at the moment, he especially detailed the three salient points — most of the other traders also — think will make MYNLD a better investment than MWC: “First, MYNLD has a higher dividend payout very good for cash-flow seekers; second, MYNLD has a much healthier balance sheet as of 1H25 at 1.0x D/E (debt-to-equity ratio), which will further improve to 0.6x post-IPO, compared to MWC’s 1.5x D/E. This will allow MYNLD to fund their substantial 2025-2027 CAPEX budget of P112.0 billon, which will be critical for the 7th rate rebasing period. Third, MYNLD’s opening cash position (OCP) of PHP100.4 billion vis-à-vis MWC’s P27.6 billion will result in higher tariff adjustments for the subsequent rebasing periods. The OCP is subjected to a 12% nominal rate of return over the course of the concession period until it goes to P0.00.” “Conversely, MWC has higher-quality assets and customers. Despite the East Concession Zone (MYNLD) is housing 10.5 million customers vs the West Concession Zone’s (MWC) 7.7 million billed volume stands relatively the same at 273 MCM (Million Cubic Meters) and 262 MCM, respectively. Furthermore, MYNLD has a long road ahead to improve its pipe infrastructure with non-revenue water at 36.7%. They aim to bring this down 20% by 2030.” In line with this, ‘M’ thinks that “there is upside for MYNLD on the listing day and thereafter, targeting it closer to the PH10y (Philippines 10-year Government Bond Yield)of 5.9%. This represents an upside of more than 10%. USD risks are minimal with most of their loans denominated in Peso and Yen.” With the exception of De la Peña, ‘M’ shares the same sentiments what the rest of the traders believe: MYNLD will not tank upon listing, it will not also be a flyer, but it will be “Climber.” – Rappler.com (The article has been prepared for general circulation for the reading public and must not be construed as an offer, or solicitation of an offer to buy or sell any securities or financial instruments whether referred to herein or otherwise. Moreover, the public should be aware that the writer or any investing parties mentioned in the column may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of their reported or mentioned investment activity. You may reach the writer at densomera@yahoo.com)
label: True
title: [ANALYSIS] Maynilad IPO: Magic mirror on the wall, who is the fairest one of all?

text: Last week, on November 7, the latest statistics on national income turned out to be a real shocker. For the third quarter of 2025, production only grew by a measly 4% from the previous year. This is the lowest quarterly growth rate of the country since 2011 (if you don’t count the pandemic). This is also very low compared to the target of the economic managers. Back in 2022, President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. targeted growth this year to be 6–8%. But when that proved unattainable, his economic managers lowered the target to 5.5–6.5%. Now, even 5.5% seems to be a moonshot: to achieve that, production in the last quarter of 2025 will have to grow by 7%! Palace spokesperson Claire Castro somehow insists this can still be done — a case of what I might call “delulunomics.” If you break down of the data, you’ll see that the third quarter of 2025 is also notable as the first quarter since the pandemic where the growth contribution of investment spending dropped. In other words, investment spending pulled down growth. A further parsing of the data will reveal that this is also the second consecutive quarter where government construction spending slumped and pulled down total investments. You might interpret this as the government being a lot more cautious in public works spending, amid the flood control scandal that President Marcos himself announced to the world back in July. This brings to mind the administration of the late Benigno Aquino III, whose anti-corruption slogan meant overly cautious government spending in the early 2010s. (This prompted them to implement the Disbursement Acceleration Program or DAP, later declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court.) One wonders: How much of economic growth is being propped up by corrupt spending? If you take away corruption, will economic growth in the past few years have been a lot lower? Worse, is there a trade-off after all between growth and corruption? On the one hand, we’re seeing years where growth is high but corruption-ridden. On the other hand, growth is weaker because the government is stamping out corruption. Is it too much to ask for high and corruption-free growth? When asked about anemic growth, President Marcos said that other factors are at play, including the multiple class and work suspensions (owing to disasters) and the fallout of Trump’s tariffs. This echoes what his chief economist said a week prior. Sure, the effects of climate change are getting more intense (as evidenced by Typhoon Tino and Super Typhoon Uwan) and Trump’s tariffs are souring the global business environment. But there’s something broken in our own backyard, and it’s getting harder and harder to deny it. Other indicators of economic malaise include the historically weak peso. On November 14, the exchange rate reached P59.11 per US dollar (as of writing) and it seems the Bangko Sentral is not too worried to let the exchange rate cross the psychological threshold of P60 per US dollar. As I wrote last week, one reason for a weaker peso is stronger demand for dollars, and this usually happens when investors want to pick up their money and invest elsewhere. Data from the Bangko Sentral also reported a steep drop of foreign direct investments (FDI): a massive 40.5% drop from August 2024 to August 2025, and a similarly alarming 22.5% drop from January to August 2024 to the same period in 2025. I can’t help but remember the numerous foreign trips made by President Marcos at the start of his presidency, supposedly to attract investments. Years later, that would be undone by large-scale corruption that he allowed to fester. So those foreign trips were useless, after all, and proved to be mere junkets that “reintroduced” the Marcoses on the global stage. In many ways, it’s not so surprising that corruption is festering under yet another Marcos presidency. But it’s also unsurprising to see that his efforts so far to curb corruption have been weak as hell. On November 13, President Marcos appeared in a press conference to update the country about his anti-corruption drive. He boasted about the 20,000 or so complaints received on the online portal “Sumbong sa Pangulo,” and encouraged people to keep on filing reports about anomalous flood control projects. But in launching this website, the President essentially outsourced the investigation to citizens, when in fact his office should be able to scan all flood control projects and pinpoint those which have been corrupted. Remember, his office sits on top of billions of pesos worth of confidential and intelligence funds! More than receiving reports, people expect Marcos to jail the corrupt. But it’s been more than three months since his State of the Nation Address, and everyone is still scot-free. Former lawmaker Zaldy Co is still globetrotting, and former public works secretary Manuel Bonoan has flown to the US. When asked about his cousin Martin Romualdez, former speaker of the House of Representatives, architect of the corrupted national budgets since 2023, President Marcos could not have been more evasive. Instead, Marcos seems to be zeroing in on small-fry scapegoats such as the conjugal contractors, Sarah and Curlee Discaya. Here in the Philippines, it’s notoriously difficult to hold public officials accountable. Heck, Filipinos keep electing the corrupt or giving them even more power than before (think Imelda Marcos and Juan Ponce Enrile, who [finally] passed away yesterday at age 101). Don’t get your hopes up that the real masterminds in the flood control mess will be jailed. And don’t get your hopes up that our economy will magically recover any time soon. – Rappler.com (Editor’s note: This article was written before Zaldy Co, in a video released on Friday, November 14, tagged President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. and former House speaker Martin Romualdez in corrupting the 2025 national budget.) JC Punongbayan, PhD is an assistant professor at the UP School of Economics and the author ofFalse Nostalgia: The Marcos “Golden Age” Myths and How to Debunk Them. In 2024, he received The Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) Award for economics. Follow him on Instagram (@jcpunongbayan).
label: True
title: [In This Economy] Economic malaise grips the Philippines

text: SAN FRANCISCO, USA – OpenAI is laying the groundwork for an initial public offering that could value the company at up to $1 trillion, three people familiar with the matter said, in what could be one of the biggest IPOs of all time. OpenAI is considering filing with securities regulators as soon as the second half of 2026, some of the people said. In preliminary discussions, the company has looked at raising $60 billion at the low end and likely more, the people said. They cautioned that talks are early and plans — including the figures and timing — could change depending on business growth and market conditions. Chief Financial Officer Sarah Friar has told some associates the company is aiming for a 2027 listing, the people said. But some advisers predict it could come even sooner, around late 2026. “An IPO is not our focus, so we could not possibly have set a date,” an OpenAI spokesperson said. “We are building a durable business and advancing our mission so everyone benefits from AGI.” The IPO preparations signal a new urgency inside the ChatGPT maker to tap public markets now that a complex restructuring is complete that reduces its reliance on Microsoft. An IPO would open the door to more efficient capital raising and enable larger acquisitions using public stock, helping to finance CEO Sam Altman’s plans to pour trillions of dollars into AI infrastructure, according to people familiar with the company’s thinking. With an annualized revenue run rate expected to reach about $20 billion by year-end, losses are also mounting inside the $500 billion company, the people said. During a livestream on Tuesday, Altman addressed the possibility of going public. “I think it’s fair to say it is the most likely path for us, given the capital needs that we’ll have,” he said. OpenAI started out as a nonprofit in 2015. A few years later, the company overhauled its structure again so that the nonprofit would have oversight and control over the for-profit arm. The main goal of the nonprofit was to ensure that OpenAI developed AI technology safely, rather than prioritizing profits like a traditional company. This week, OpenAI revamped itself yet again. It is still controlled by a nonprofit, now called the OpenAI Foundation, but the nonprofit has a 26% stake in OpenAI Group and a warrant to receive additional shares if the company hits certain milestones. This change makes the nonprofit a significant stakeholder in OpenAI’s financial success. A successful offering would mark a major win for investors such as SoftBank, Thrive Capital, and Abu Dhabi’s MGX. Microsoft, one of its biggest backers, now owns about 27% of the company after investing $13 billion. The deliberations come as AI is driving a surge in public markets. Earlier this year, AI cloud company CoreWeave went public at a $23 billion valuation and has roughly tripled since. On Wednesday, Nvidia became the first company to reach a $5 trillion market value, powered by a rally that has cemented its role at the center of the global AI boom. The Wall Street Journal first reported on the possibility of OpenAI going public as early as 2027. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: OpenAI lays groundwork for juggernaut IPO at up to $1-trillion valuation

text: MANILA, Philippines – Michael V has suited up to portray controversial figure Sarah Discaya after social media users pointed out his striking resemblance to the public works contractor. Discaya made headlines anew in early September when she admitted during a Senate probe that there were instances when her nine construction firms bid for the same government flood control projects. The businesswoman had initially denied the allegations, but after further prodding from Senator Jinggoy Estrada (who was later tagged in alleged flood control kickbacks in Bulacan), Discaya admitted the scheme. But it wasn’t just Discaya’s revelation that stuck out to the public — it was her resemblance to popular Kapuso comedian Michael V. Memes comparing the two figures’ features had begun to surface, and before long, GMA gag show Bubble Gang teased footage and photos of Michael V dressed in a similar garb as that of Discaya’s. In the photos posted by Bubble Gang, Michael V had on a wig mimicking Discaya’s hairstyle, two moles in the same spots Discaya has them on her face, glasses, and similar outfit — consisting of an inner top and blazer. In one photo, Michael V was also holding an umbrella, seemingly alluding to Discaya’s statement in an interview with TV and YouTube personality Julius Babao that she bought one of her luxury vehicles, a Rolls-Royce, because she liked the umbrella built into the car door. Michael V’s character was named Ciala Dismaya, a play on Sarah Discaya’s name, appearing to be referring to the Filipino slang term of shala (meaning fancy) and dismaya (disappointment). The Discayas’ legal counsel, Cornelio Samaniego III, told GMA News that Sarah is aware of Michael V’s impersonation of her. Samaniego debunked rumors that Discaya was angry at the comedian for the skit — adding that the businesswoman is okay with it. The Bubble Gang episode will premiere on Sunday, September 14, at 6:10 pm on GMA Network. Sarah Discaya’s construction firms have since been disqualified from bidding for government projects. The former Pasig City mayoral candidate and her husband, Pacifico “Curlee” Discaya, have also expressed their desire to become state witnesses in the flood control project scandal. (FAST FACTS: On becoming a state witness) – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Uncanny resemblance? Michael V stars as Ciala Dismaya in ‘Bubble Gang’

text: When was the last time you entered a room and felt the weight of responsibility and possibility at the same time? As an Asia 21 fellow this year, I asked myself this as I walked into the Asia 21 Next Generation Fellows Summit this December 5 to 7 held in Manila, my first gathering as part of the 2025 cohort. I had imagined the moment for years. Back in college, I remember reading about Asia 21 Fellows who were shaping policy, building communities, and challenging systems. I followed their stories like a student studying constellations that are visible, distant, but guiding. And suddenly, there I was, no longer just looking up at the stars but meeting them, learning with them, and realizing I now shared the responsibility to shine. The summit, organized by Asia Society Philippines and led by Natalie Ching Jorge, Doris Magsaysay Ho, and Fernando Zobel De Ayala, was a powerful reminder that leadership isn’t a title, it’s a lifelong practice of courage, humility, and service. Standing beside co-fellows I had only ever read about (including my 2025 co-fellow Filipino classmate Kenneth Abante), I felt the quiet thrill of belonging to a circle of people who still believe that change is possible, that institutions can evolve, and that communities deserve leaders who listen as much as they act. The Asia Society website framed our selection as a recognition of courageous leadership. But for me, it felt more like an invitation: now that you are here, what will you do with this space? The question followed me all the way to Palawan for the Asia 21 travel caravan. And as if the universe wanted to insist on an answer, it sent us two Filipino Asia 21 Fellows whose journeys could fill entire books. Amina Swananpoel (Class of 2011), executive director of Roots of Health, has dedicated her life to reproductive rights, dignity, and women’s health in Palawan, a work that is rarely glamorous but always life-changing. Walking through their clinic and community spaces felt like stepping inside a living manifesto of compassion. Her work reminds us that development is not measured in impressive metrics but in whether people feel safer, healthier, and more human. Then there was Quintin Pastrana (Class of 2008), someone I had long admired from afar for his clean energy advocacy and his leadership in Sabang Renewable Energy Corporation. Seeing Sabang’s microgrid in person, an award-winning model of hybrid renewable power, was grounding. Quintin didn’t just talk about climate solutions; he built one in a place where energy once meant diesel, darkness, or none at all. Quintin and I had the chance to briefly talk about collaboration for climate solutions, a conversation that felt less like planning and more like anchoring shared values. He also mentioned something that delighted me: the capstone of Asian Institute Management MDM graduates — Carl Vincent Gapasin, Xien Palacios and Novee Nalica. Their research explores how solar panels can coexist with agriculture, a topic that mirrors the very spirit of Sabang’s hybrid systems. Knowing about their academic work intersects with real-world energy transitions reminded me that the pipeline of Filipino climate innovators is stronger than we think. Sometimes, all they need is a platform, and mentors like Quintin who are willing to lift them into the conversation. What do we teach in business school, really? Two weeks before Palawan and the Summit, I stepped into another room, this time as keynote speaker at the National Business Management Conference of De La Salle University and the Philippine Academy of Management. It was a gathering of scholars, deans, researchers, and students. And in my mind, I carried the faces of farmers I work with, entrepreneurs trying to survive, and community leaders who measure success in meals fed, hectares restored, or dreams made possible. So, I asked the room a question I ask myself often: Do we teach business to make profit, or do we teach business to make impact? This wasn’t rhetorical. It was an invitation to rethink the systems that shape young leaders at the very beginning of their trajectories. For decades, business education has been framed around competition, market share, and bottom lines. But in a world facing climate breakdown, inequity, and fragility, what kind of leaders are we producing if we don’t anchor the curriculum in justice, sustainability, and human dignity? In my keynote, I shared what we have been building through Varacco, ThinnkFarm, and our Smart FARM and Smart CAFE projects: that businesses can be profitable and transformative; that technology — IoT, drones, nano-biofertilizers — can be democratized for farmers; that growth can be regenerative, not extractive. Platforms like the National Business Management Conference and PAoM matter because they create space for dialogue. They allow professors, researchers, and practitioners to ask uncomfortable questions, interrogate outdated frameworks, and co-design future-ready models. Amid the complexity of our time, these spaces remind us that business can still be a force for good, if we intentionally teach it that way. Looking back, the past weeks felt like a single arc stitched across three locations: A summit hall in Manila, where young leaders gathered with clarity and conviction. A microgrid in Palawan, reminding me of what climate solutions look like when they reach the people who need them most. A conference stage in De La Salle, where I stood before academics and asked them, and myself — what kind of leaders we must nurture for the next decade. (READ: Supporting social enterprises with a purpose: Should we?) In every space, one theme emerged: courageous leadership is not about being the smartest person in the room; it is about being the most accountable to the future. Meeting Amina re-centered me on dignity. Learning from Quintin re-energized me on climate action. Seeing the brilliance of AIM graduates like Carl, Xien, and Novee reminded me that the next generation is already experimenting with the ideas that will define the Philippines’ sustainable future. And speaking to educators and scholars challenged me to imagine a business landscape where young entrepreneurs do not have to choose between profit and purpose, because the ecosystem teaches them to integrate both. I return to the question I asked at the summit: Now that you are here, what will you do with this space? For me, the answer is simple: keep building, keep convening, keep learning, and keep connecting the threads, between fellows and farmers, between energy systems and education, between research and real life. Spaces like Asia 21, Roots of Health, Sabang’s microgrid, and the national business conference are not just events; they are reminders that progress is collaborative. That no leader moves alone. That the world is held up by communities of people quietly doing the work, even when the world is not watching. And if there is anything this season has taught me, it is this: “Hope is not a feeling. It is a practice. And courageous leadership is one of its fiercest forms.” – Rappler.com Ariestelo Asilo is recently named an Asia 21 Next Generation Fellow 2025. He is the President and CEO of www.varacco.com and www.thinnkfarm.com which operate through social entrepreneurship selling Buy 1 Take 1 Coffee, and creating farmer-scientists in coffee production in Mindanao. Currently, he is taking his Doctorate in Sustainability at the University of the Philippines-Open University. He also has a cat named Libe which he found at the Liberica farm in Cavite. telo@varacco.com
label: True
title: [Good Business] Lessons from Asia 21, Palawan, and the future of business leadership

text: MANILA, Philippines – In one of the rare infrastructure undertakings of the Sy family, Iloilo City in Western Visayas now has public markets redeveloped by SM Prime Holdings Incorporated, the Philippines’ largest mall developer and operator founded by the late Henry Sy. Built under a public-private partnership (PPP), Iloilo City and SM Prime opened to the public on October 30 the redeveloped Iloilo Central Market, also known as Tienda Mayor, and the Iloilo Terminal Market, the bagsakan or drop-off area for goods traded in Panay Island. The two markets, built decades ago, are located in Iloilo City’s Cultural Tourism Heritage Zone and Historic Center. The redevelopment seeks to preserve and enhance the city’s old commercial business district and help improve the city’s tourism. From drab and unsightly, the new markets have been transformed into bright and clean spaces for the city’s micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs). “Before, the old market’s condition was really difficult for us. When it rained, everything got wet, and our regular customers found it inconvenient,” said Jedda Navales, a native coffee vendor. “Now, with the new Iloilo Terminal Market, we’re finally leveling up.” SM Prime spent P3 billion to redevelop the two buildings, which it described as “two of the city’s historic public spaces.“ With additional floors, the Iloilo Central Market now has a gross floor area (GFA) of 17,000 square meters, while the Iloilo Terminal Market has a GFA of 20,000 sqm. The redevelopment projects, solicited for PPP by the local government unit, were undertaken at no cost to the Iloilo City government. SM Prime president Jeffrey Lim said the projects do not signify a new business field for the conglomerate. “This is more to support entrepreneurs which is part of how we do business and as we move to provincial areas so we can create shared growth between us and the MSMEs,” Lim said in a press briefing on Monday, November 10. Lim added that SM Prime currently has no other public market redevelopment projects in its pipeline, but that it is open to working with other local government units (LGUs) to help local entrepreneurs. The PPP was signed in August 2022 between then-Iloilo City mayor Jerry Treñas and SM Prime, and the projects were opened to the public by his successor, daughter Raisa Treñas-Chu, and SM Engineering Design and Development president Hans Sy Jr., a grandson of SM founder Henry Sy. The redevelopment of the Iloilo Central Market, built in the 1920s, expanded the central market section, increasing the space available for vendors (fish and meat, dried fish, flower shops, rice and grains, frozen food) from 529 to 850. This area will be managed by the Iloilo City government. Unlike before, the Iloilo Central Market now has ramps and an elevator for easier access to the two upper floors. In addition, the Iloilo Central Market now has 61 long-term leasable spaces and communal areas which will be handled by SM Prime and from which it hopes to recover its investment. SM Prime said this area includes dining areas where Ilonggo dishes such as batchoy and pancit molo will be available. Iloilo is the Philippines’ first UNESCO Creative City of Gastronomy. The Iloilo Terminal Market’s market section, on the other hand, now has spaces for 1,160 vendors from the previous 911. Plus, it now has a lifestyle center in the upper floors with 58 long-term leasable spaces to be handled by SM Prime. SM Supermalls president Steven Tan said the the redeveloped public markets will be fully operational by the end of November. He said the focus in the redevelopment was on hygiene “making sure everything was clean,” including recycling, the sewage treatment plant, and water supply, and improving access. “We have professionalized this and we added more parking to make it more convenient for people who go to the market,” Tan said. “This day marks an important milestone in the history of Iloilo City, a new beginning for our vendors and shoppers. Everything is organized, clean, bright and well-ventilated,” said Treñas-Chu during the soft opening ceremony on October 30. “This project raises the bar and serves as a model of how the private and public sectors can work hand in hand to deliver meaningful, lasting benefits for communities,” the LGU also said in a statement. In a statement on September 22, the Iloilo City Local Economic Enterprise Office (LEEO) clarified that the Iloilo Central Market was “not privatized.” “SM will only manage their designated area, while the rest of the market operations remain under the Local Economic Enterprise Office (LEEO),” it said. It also denied that rent for each of the market space will go up from P900 per month to P5,000 per month. “No such increase has been implemented. In fact, under Executive Order No. 21, the City Government has deferred any adjustment in market rental rates for two years, covering 2025 to 2026,” the LGU office said. SM Prime will manage and maintain the facility under a 25-year lease with the Iloilo City government. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: If SM were to redevelop your city’s palengke, what would it look like?

text: MANILA, Philippines — Nearly four years after IKEA opened in Pasay City the world’s biggest IKEA branch, the Swedish home furnishing brand cemented its presence in the northern part of Metro Manila, with a new concept shop now open in TriNoma Mall, Quezon City. IKEA and Ayala Malls collaborated to bring the first-ever “Plan and Order Shop” to the country, just six months after the two teams’ first meeting. More than a place to shop for homeware and furniture, the smaller Quezon City branch also has a new planning studio. This allows customers to consult with planning specialists on how to arrange their homes with the right furniture and home decor pieces, even if it’s a tight-knit space. Customization is at the center of this new home improvement experience. “[The Plan and Order Shop] is a quite brand new concept for IKEA in our retail operation. It’s a way to bring our range closer to the many Filipinos,” said IKEA Philippines country retail manager Ricardo Pinheiro at the branch opening on October 23, Thursday. Apart from accessibility to different sectors with its free planning service, Swedish Ambassador-Designate Anna Ferry also emphasized the store’s display of the core values that IKEA and Sweden stand for. “Most importantly, [IKEA promotes a] business sector [that] is ethically sustainable, oriented with people and the planet in mind,” she said. Ferry highlighted the trust and belief IKEA has in the Philippines, as seen in its willingness to invest and expand stores in the country through the opening of the Plan and Order Shop. Also present at the branch opening, Quezon City Mayor Joy Belmonte pointed out the opportunities for the new IKEA branch with its strategic location in the northern part of the capital region. “[Quezon City is] the largest city in the Philippines with a population of 3.2 million. As said earlier, all of [IKEA’s] customers, or many of [IKEA’s] customers in Pasay are actually from [here],” she said. She added the advantage of the branch’s location at the center of other big local government units. With the city recently being recognized as the Hall of Fame Awardee for being one of the most business-friendly LGUs in the country, the IKEA branch is further proof of the LGU’s move towards growth in the business sector. Belmonte also acknowledged the Ayala Corporation, which she says has been a “close partner of the local government of Quezon City” and has ensured continuous progress in Quezon City. Mariana Zobel de Ayala, currently head of the Leasing and Hospitality Group of Ayala, shared that TriNoma was a mall intentionally built for the city and its people. “We really wanted to serve the dynamic and incredible, and large community that’s here in Quezon City,” she said. With the Plan and Order shop’s location, its services have become within reach of Quezon City’s diverse population living in condos, townhouses, and smaller houses. Zobel de Ayala emphasized that the partnership with IKEA is more than just a business expansion. Beyond offering accessibility to Quezon City and northern residents, she said that the Plan and Order Shop format aligns with IKEA’s vision of inclusive and customer-centric spaces that “elevate everyday life.” “Over the past year, we’ve been looking to move with purpose. [We] reimagine our goals beyond just commercial centers, but really, as the vibrant and future-ready destinations that will continue to inspire, to push, and to engage all of the communities that we serve.” Housing IKEA’s second branch is only one of the steps the Ayala Group is taking towards transforming TriNoma into a space that addresses the lifestyle and needs of its community. – Alyana Fabella/Rappler.com Alyana Fabella is a Rappler intern studying Bachelor of Arts in Communication at the Ateneo de Manila University.
label: True
title: What IKEA’s new TriNoma branch means for QC’s bustling business scene

text: MANILA, Philippines – The Department of Tourism (DOT) and TikTok Philippines on Tuesday, October 21, signed a memorandum of agreement to help micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) promote their goods and services on the social media platform. The DOT and TikTok Philippines’ collaboration entails training DOT-accredited vendors on short-form video content creation and online marketing through a series of workshops nationwide. The collaboration will target MSMEs such as small hotels, travel agencies, souvenir shops, and tourism groups. DOT Secretary Christina Frasco said the first training camp will be held through a one-day hybrid setup in November for 50 MSMEs in Metro Manila and Cebu. Frasco, who hails from Cebu, said the province’s tourism sector had been devastated by the recent earthquakes that devastated Bogo City and the province’s other northern areas. The tourism chief added that the end goal of the DOT’s partnership with TikTok is to increase the revenues and market penetration of MSMEs in the sector, which she hopes will translate into more tourist arrivals. The Philippines logged 2.9 million arrivals in the first half of 2025, and the tourism sector is expected to contribute P2.7 trillion to the Philippine economy this year. The country missed its 7.7 million arrival target in 2024 amid the postponed e-visa program for the Chinese market, as well as geopolitical tensions. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: DOT, TikTok ink partnership to boost reach of MSMEs in tourism sector

text: MANILA, Philippines – Retired air force general Romeo Poquiz was arrested upon landing at the Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA) over a warrant of arrest from an inciting to sedition charge filed against him by the Philippine National Police (PNP). Poquiz’s lawyer Ferdinand Topacio was in the process of posting the P48,000 bail at the Quezon City Regional Trial Court when Rappler spoke to him past noon on Monday, January 5. Poquiz was arrested in NAIA past 8 am on Monday after arriving from a weeks-long family vacation in Thailand. “We just need his physical presence [in the court], I hope [he can be released within the day],” Topacio told Rappler over the phone. Poquiz is an outspoken critic of the Marcos administration, and is allied with groups supporting former president Rodrigo Duterte. He is a lead organizer of the September rallies against infrastructure corruption, but ones which were perceived to be politically motivated to elevate the Duterte bloc over Marcos. The rallies of their group, United People’s Initiative (UPI), was heavily scrutinized by both the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) and the local city government of Quezon City for alleged speeches that incite to sedition. The Quezon City government stopped the third day of the UPI rallies in November for alleged seditious tendencies. Poquiz’s name was also floated as one of the alleged instigators of a planned coup last November, but he has since clarified that his group spoke to AFP chief Gen. Romeo Brawner Jr. “only to air our legitimate grievances,” and not to urge the military to withdraw its support for Marcos, he told One News on November 19. “I did not,” Poquiz said when asked if he specifically tried to convince Brawner to withdraw military support. But according to Poquiz’s lawyer, Levito Baligod, the complaint filed by the Criminal Investigation and Detection Group (CIDG) stemmed from a Facebook post, and not the UPI protests, nor the discussion with Brawner. The Facebook post, Baligod said, read: “Kailangan mag-seryoso ang gobyerno na mag-imbestiga sa anomalya dahil kung hindi, baka isipin ng mga tao na ang mastermind ay nasa Malacañang.” (The government needs to be serious in investigating the anomalies because if not, Filipinos might think that the mastermind is in Malacañang.) Rebellion and inciting to sedition complaints were filed, but only the latter charge progressed at the Quezon City Regional Trial Court Branch 77. The first hearing over the complaint was on October 15, and the warrant was issued way back December 5. Under Article 139 of the Revised Penal Code, sedition is “committed by persons who rise publicly and tumultuously in order to attain by force” actions that threaten government and social stability. “Inciting” under Article 142 is defined as “any person who, without taking any direct part in the crime of sedition, should incite others to the accomplishment of any of the acts which constitute sedition, by means of speeches, proclamations, writings, emblems, cartoons, banners, or other representations tending to the same end.” The Duterte administration also used this legal tool to go after critics. Staunch Duterte critic Antonio Trillanes IV was also charged of the same, and again this time, state prosecutors used the rule of “dangerous tendency.” In the Trillanes case, which he has since been cleared of, state prosecutors said there was dangerous tendency “when the words uttered or published could easily produce disaffection among the people and a state of feeling in them incompatible with a disposition to remain loyal to the government and obedient to the laws.” Ironically for Poquiz who is allied with pro-Duterte groups, state prosecutors also used the dangerous tendency rule against him. “The city prosecutor used an obsolete standard in evaluating whether the utterance incited or not [to sedition.] The city prosecutor used the old standard dangerous tendency, but there have been many Supreme Court decisions removing that standard, and we have a new standard called ‘clear and present danger’,” Baligod told Rappler. Clear and present danger, according to Supreme Court jurisprudence, has a two-way test: Duterte, during his presidency, cracked down on all kinds of dissent too, which for free speech advocates did not meet the clear and present danger standard. It’s not the first time that Marcos has used the same Duterte playbook against critics. Even protesters during his inauguration in 2022 were threatened with the same charges, and then again against the progressive bloc of protesters during the November 30 anti-corruption rally last year. Baligod said the charges were filed in court even though they had filed a motion for reconsideration (MR) before the Department of Justice (DOJ), which is still pending. Generally, prosecutors wait for the resolution of an MR to file charges in court, but the Duterte-time DOJ had often opted not to wait, too. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Retired general arrested for inciting to sedition for Facebook post vs Marcos

text: On Thursday, October 9, Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) Chair Francis Lim apologized for citing a “fictitious” industry report that claimed the Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) lost P1.7 trillion in market value in just three weeks in August. August was when President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. shared that just 15 contractors bagged contracts to 20% of all flood control projects nationwide. The chief of the corporate watchdog cited the fake figure during a speech at a Financial Executives Institute of the Philippines forum this week, where he also noted that investors were leaving the Philippines due to weak integrity. Lim has since retracted his statement, saying he fell victim to the fake report that was circulating within business circles. “I deeply regret any confusion or concern that my statement may have caused. My sole intent was to underscore the vital importance of integrity in our markets and the devastating impact corruption can have on investor confidence,” he said in a statement on Thursday, October 9. Special Assistant to the President for Investment and Economic Affairs Frederick Go, earlier on Thursday, dismissed Lim’s claims, saying that the SEC chief cited a fake report that has since been disowned by Standard & Poor’s (S&P) market intelligence unit. So, how much market value was really wiped out in the weeks Lim referenced in his speech? PSE president Ramon Monzon clarified that the PSE lost around P185 billion in market capital in those three weeks. The local bourse’s weekly reports logged the following market capitalization figures since Marcos launched the Sumbong sa Pangulo website: Despite the erroneous figure in Lim’s speech, Monzon agreed with the SEC chief’s sentiments that corruption has hurt investor confidence. “​​That being said, SEC Chairman Francis Ed. Lim is correct in assailing the level of corruption in the country, and its adverse effects on the economy and financial markets,” he noted. According to Rizal Commercial Banking Corporation’s chief economist Michael Ricafort, the PSE’s composite index PSEi declined by at least 5% since Marcos’ fourth State of the Nation Address in July. Waning business confidence also led the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) to cut the country’s policy rate by 0.25% to just 4.75% in its latest monetary policy meeting, in a bid to reverse the fall. “The stock market has declined, and there are now fewer companies with expansion plans. Weaker growth means weaker demand and lower inflation,” said BSP Governor Eli Remolona Jr. Ricafort explained in an email to Rappler that the latest rate cut was one of the offsetting factors for the PSEi on Thursday’s trade. He emphasized the importance of boosting economic growth through monetary easing measures in order to make borrowing costs cheaper. This, in turn, will increase demand for credit to spur investments, employment, and other activities that will boost economic growth. In a Thursday press briefing, the BSP also called for what Remolona described as a credible resolution to the corruption scandal. BSP Deputy Governor Zeno Abenoja also mentioned reforms in the implementation of future national budgets that ensure projects are properly implemented. “We would like to see, for example, for the 2026 to 2027 budget, in the implementation, what is allotted for certain key items will result in full implementation of this project, less leakages. That would improve the outlook for domestic demand, and that could support the economy moving forward,” he said. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: How much market value did the PSE really lose amid flood control projects mess?

text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia – Trade negotiations between the Philippines and United States continue three months after President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. trekked to Washington, DC, to meet US President Donald Trump in the Oval Office. Speaking to reporters on the sidelines of the 47th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Malaysia on Monday, October 27, Palace press officer Undersecretary Claire Castro said there are “comprehensive issues” that must be tackled first, as the two nations iron out the fine details of the agreement. Castro was citing Frederick Go, Marcos’ special assistant for investment and economic affairs. The issues, Go told Castro, include trade rules and regulations, non-tariff measures such as services and investments, and products that the Philippines wants to “protect” such as rice, sugar, and chicken, and exports such as coconuts, pineapple, electronics. “At ‘yan po, ilan po ito sa mga hindi po sa ngayon makakayang i-negotiate ng basta-basta ng Pilipinas. So nando’n pa rin po ang pakikipag-usap para po ‘yung ibang mga produkto natin ay hindi na nga po maapektuhan,” said Castro. (So those are among the reasons why, for now, it’s hard for the Philippines to negotiate [with the US]. We are still in discussions to ensure that our products are not affected [adversely].) On the sidelines of the 47th ASEAN Summit, the United States signed trade agreements with the bloc’s chair Malaysia, as well as Cambodia. The US also signed framework trade deals with Vietnam and Thailand. In late July 2025, following a meeting with Marcos in the Oval Office, Trump announced a 19% rate for the Philippines, and claimed zero tariffs for US products entering the Philippines. Prior to that meeting, Trump announced the US would be imposing a 20% tariff on Philippine products, a rate that was three percentage points higher than the 17% that was initially planned to be imposed on Manila. The 19% rate was meant to kick in on August 1. Negotiations have been ongoing since then. Philippine Ambassador to the US Jose Manuel “Babe” Romualdez told Rappler the conclusion of talks is “not too far [away].” – Rappler.com
label: True
title: 3 months later, US-Philippine trade negotiations not done yet

text: MANILA, Philippines – Acquisition by another tycoon. That’s the response of the troubled PrimeWater to mounting grievances by its millions of consumers who now call the Villar-led company “crime water.” The Villar group confirmed on Tuesday, December 16, that 100% of PrimeWater had been acquired by Crystal Bridges Holding Corporation, the investment firm of Puregold tycoon Lucio Co. Crystal Bridges is owned by Co’s children, with Puregold heir Vincent Co as chairman and president, according to the company’s 2025 general information sheet. “Crystal Bridges Holding Corporation of the Lucio Co Group has entered into definitive agreements for the acquisition of 100% of PrimeWater Infrastructure Corp,” the Villar group said in a statement Tuesday. Crystal Bridges will take over in the middle of multiple investigations and local governments wanting to preterminate all over the country. On the ground in Bacolod City, consumers are frustrated by the sale. “Now that PrimeWater is in hot water, it is simply being sold to another private entity. Is this the solution? Where is the accountability? Will PrimeWater be allowed to walk away without consequences? Is this yet another attempt to fool the Bacolodnons?” the Bacolod City Water District Employees Union said in a statement. Bacolod City just averted a major water crisis this weekend. PrimeWater had not paid three months of outstanding bills to its water supplier, and the subcontractor had threatened to cut the water line. Emergency negotiations ended in a clutch commitment by PrimeWater to pay on Saturday, December 13, or a day after the deadline. PrimeWater not paying its subcontractors is not an isolated incident as Rappler had reported on another contractor involved in at least two water districts. Senator Raffy Tulfo, chair of the Senate public works committee investigating PrimeWater’s failure of obligations in at least half of its nearly 80 joint venture agreements, had also cited another case of an unpaid contractor. In Himamaylan, Negros Occidental, the local council wants full transparency of what the Co group’s acquisition will entail. Vice Mayor Justin Dominic Gatuslao told Rappler over a phone call on Wednesday, December 17, that the local government was not informed beforehand, and that “it turns out even the members of the board of the water district were not aware of the transaction.” Gatuslao said the next move of the council will be to ask the water district for the strategy with the Co group. “What are our non-negotiables and what is it that we want to push considering that we want to take this as a new opportunity, a fresh start so that we can finally take off from a solid foundation?” said Gatuslao, who described the Villar group operation as “definitely a failure.” In San Fernando, Pampanga, Mayor Vilma Caluag told Rappler over a phone call Tuesday evening that they are not keen on giving PrimeWater a second chance even with different management. The mayor appealed to the new owners, “Palayain na nila kami, pakawalan na nila kami, nagmakakaawa ako sa kanila para naman mabawasan naman ang challenges namin sa siyudad ng San Fernando.” (Free us, let us go, I’m begging them, so we could ease the challenges we face here in the city of San Fernando.) Caluag unilaterally suspended PrimeWater’s business permit in her city, which is now being pitched as a blueprint for other localities that want out of the 25-year deal. The water district, which is under the Local Water Utilities Administration, had also preterminated the contract, according to Caluag. But PrimeWater’s technique has always been to take to court whoever attempts to break free, and “most of the time,” they win, said Tulfo during a Senate hearing. Caluag said PrimeWater had been allowed three catch-up plans in San Fernando, but services did not improve. Since doing a full offensive on PrimeWater, Caluag said the constituents have experienced some relief in water services. “Ayaw na naming magkasuhan, wala naman kaming ibubuga kapag kasuhan na. Sana palayain na lang nila kami, makapag-move on na kami, at makapagtrabaho na kami nang maayos.” (We don’t want a legal battle anymore, we don’t stand a chance. So, I hope they let us go so we can move on, and we can get to work.) In metropolitan La Union, the water district is still locked in a legal battle over pretermination. The Water for the People Network La Union said the sale was just a “pure business transaction” that “did not answer fundamental questions” about the joint venture. “Hindi dapat payagan na makalusot lang ang mga Villar sa kanilang perwisyo sa mamamayan. Dapat pagbayarin sila ng danyos sa mga konsyumer na pinagkaitan nila ng maayos na serbisyo sa tubig,” the group said in a statement sent to Rappler on Wednesday. (We should not allow the Villars to get away with the damage they have caused the community. They should be made to pay damages to consumers they deprived of good water service.) Hospitality business owners in surf town San Juan, La Union, who have been impacted by the water disruptions, said that while the sale “may invite reassessment… the sale of PrimeWater does not extinguish existing service obligations.” “Consumers must not be made to shoulder the cost of PrimeWater’s operational and management failures,” said Monalisa Luebben-Binlot, president of the San Juan Resort Restaurant and Hotel Association. Prior to the acquisition, PrimeWater was wholly owned by Prime Asset Ventures of Manuel Paolo Villar, the son of former senator Manny Villar, and brother of senators Mark Villar and Camille Villar. It was during the time of Mark Villar as secretary of the Department of Public Works and Highways under the Duterte administration when PrimeWater rapidly grew, increasing its joint venture agreements by five-fold. From 15 JVAs by the end of 2015, they now have 77 JVAs nationwide. Half have been wanting to forfeit PrimeWater’s performance bond, according to Rappler’s analysis of audit reports, and half have been wanting to preterminate the contracts, according to Tulfo’s survey of its partner water districts. Kabataan Representative Renee Co told Rappler in an earlier interview that PrimeWater under Villar should be criminally investigated “for estafa, syndicated estafa, and graft, if officials are involved.” “The government should freeze assets and require performance bonds to make sure contractors, water districts, and consumers get paid and protected,” said Co. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Lucio Co group buys troubled PrimeWater, consumers still aggrieved

text: A few days ago, the Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism (PCIJ) came out with smoking gun evidence that unprogrammed appropriations or funds have been used for infrastructure projects in at least the past two years. Prior to this, our closest confirmation came from an admission of House appropriations committee chair Mika Suansing. In a plenary session, Suansing said that “The UA releases for flood control projects for 2023 is P34 billion, and for 2024, it is P107 billion. So across 2023 and 2024, the UA releases for the flood control project is P141 billion.” But now, PCIJ has the goods. Specifically, PCIJ was able to get its hands on Special Allotment Release Orders (SAROs). These documents are issued by the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) authorizing the release of money for items lodged in unprogrammed funds. PCIJ found that P213.8 billion of unprogrammed funds were released for public works, and over half of them (52%) were for flood control, followed by roads and bridges (38%), and multipurpose buildings or facilities (8.5%). What’s more, in the SAROs they got, the stated purpose of these projects were “To cover the implementation of various priority projects which are crucial in ensuring the achievement of the President’s Eight-Point Socioeconomic Agenda.” In short, Marcos had a direct hand in approving anomalous flood control projects from start to finish: from the crafting of the proposed budget (National Expenditure Program) all the way to the release of SAROs. This only emphasizes the fact that he can’t wash his hands and feign ignorance or surprise about all these projects. And remember that these documents that PCIJ got refer to releases in 2023 and 2024. Dubious infra projects have been going on for quite some time now, and it’s impossible for Marcos to know nothing about these anomalies. Either he’s terribly corrupt for allowing all these pork projects (no surprises there) or he’s terribly stupid for not knowing anything about them (an unlikely scenario). Very clearly, unprogrammed funds have emerged as the new receptacle for pork allocations. Despite this, authorities continue to claim that they’re innocuous. On October 29, in a recent forum in Clark, Undersecretary Goddes Libiran of the DBM spewed disinformation during the question and answer portion. To her mild surprise, someone in the audience asked, “Is it true that unprogrammed funds are pork barrel? What are UAs (unprogrammed appropriations)? How is it released?” She replied that for unprogrammed funds to be qualified as pork, it should be a huge lump-sum fund that could be spent on yet unidentified projects. But UA is not like that, Libiran said. This is false. UA is precisely a lump-sum fund. If you check in the General Appropriations Act, for a number of years there’s a line item called “Support for Infrastructure Projects and Social Programs” (later called SAGIP or “Strengthening Assistance for Government Infrastructure and Social Programs”) that do not specify at all what projects will be spent on. For the 2026 budget, this is exactly what Congress modified, to stop the abuse of unprogrammed funds in the past. Specifically, under the leadership of Rep. Suansing, they removed “I” or infrastructure, so SAGIP is now just “Strengthening Assistance for Government Social Programs” or SAGP. This is an acknowledgement that unprogrammed funds had been abused in the past as a lump-sum fund for corruptible public works. The PCIJ documents prove this. Undersecretary Libiran added that the release of UA is very strict (but also said in the same breath, it’s “very lenient”). UA is supposedly not a discretionary fund of DBM, because agencies like the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) are the ones who request and justify the release. So as long as the documents are complete, including a certification from the Treasury that there are excess funds, Libiran said they must release the funds (otherwise the Commission on Audit will go after them). But this points to a missing piece of the puzzle: where are the certifications coming from the Treasury that excess funds do exist? The DBM needs these documents to release money for unprogrammed appropriations. But it’s highly doubtful that there exist excess revenues to justify the release of hundreds of billions of pesos for unprogrammed funds. Also, just because the DPWH requests the release of unprogrammed funds doesn’t mean that DBM has no discretion at all in the release of funds. In fact, they have too much discretion. The budget law itself states that “prioritization of funding of the purposes under the UA” should follow a priority list, and infrastructure projects are low on that list (following personnel benefits, social services, government counterpart of foreign-assisted projects). But in the next provision there’s a loophole: “the order of priority may be modified to support the funding of urgent or implementation-ready projects,” including “the 8-Point Socioeconomic Agenda.” This, I realize, is the loophole that DBM can use to justify release of UA for public works (as confirmed by the documents PCIJ gathered). Near the end of the provisions for unprogrammed funds, it also states that, “The DBM is hereby authorized to approve the… modification of amounts within the authorized purposes” and “use of amounts under Purposes of the UA, except the Budgetary Support to GOCCs (Government-Owned and -Controlled Corporations) and the Support to Foreign-Assisted Projects.” In other words, the DBM has wide latitude on how unprogrammed funds will be prioritized and released. What this all suggests is that there’s more to the DBM-DPWH relationship than meets the eye. I hope this gets revealed in the hearings of the Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI), but frankly I’m not hoping that their investigations will amount to much. On Facebook, I called out the “fake news” that Undersecretary Libiran was saying in the Clark event. She replied lengthily, including: “Supreme Court na nga nagsabi na constitutional and legal ang UA, and it is different from pork barrel, pinipilit mo pa rin?” (No less than the Supreme Court has said that UA is constitutional and legal, and it is different from pork barrel, and you’re still insisting otherwise?) The thing is, the Supreme Court has yet to try and decide on a case alleging that unprogrammed funds are unconstitutional. The rebuttal itself includes fake news! At any rate, unprogrammed funds have indeed evolved as the newest iteration of pork: bloated lump-sum funds that allow for post-enactment discretionary spending by the DBM and other agencies, at the behest of politicians. If that’s not pork, I don’t know what is. Sadly, the House version of the 2026 budget promises to include at least P243 billion in unprogrammed funds. The Senate vows to remove this, but let’s see how far they can go about it. I expect budget deliberations to be railroaded up until December, with pork allocations safe and sound. Tuloy pa rin ang ligaya (The happiness continues), I’m afraid to say. – Rappler.com JC Punongbayan, PhD is an assistant professor at the UP School of Economics and the author ofFalse Nostalgia: The Marcos “Golden Age” Myths and How to Debunk Them. In 2024, he received The Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) Award for economics. Follow him on Instagram (@jcpunongbayan).
label: True
title: [In This Economy] Unprogrammed funds: The new pork

text: MANILA, Philippines – The Lopez family’s property firm Rockwell Land Corporation (Rockwell Land) bought a nearly 75% stake in Alabang Town Center from the Madrigal family for P21.6 billion. In a disclosure late Monday, December 22, Rockwell Land said it had acquired 75% of Alabang Commercial Corporation (ACC), the company that owns Alabang Town Center, from the Madrigals led by real estate developer Francisco Madrigal Bayot, a grandson of former senator and industrialist Vicente Madrigal. “Earlier this year, Mr. Francisco ‘Jun’ M. Bayot invited us to consider redeveloping Alabang Town Center. It presented a compelling opportunity for Rockwell Land to further expand our presence in the south of Metro Manila, particularly given the scale and long-term potential of the property,” Rockwell Land chairman and CEO Nestor Padilla said in a press release on Monday. “We are very grateful to Mr. Bayot and the Madrigal family for this opportunity. Our immediate focus is on ensuring a smooth transition and planning its redevelopment,” he added. Other shareholders of ACC who were part of the share purchase agreement are: Rockwell Land will pay ACC P21.6 billion in three equal installments every December over the next three years. The purchase was announced six days after Ayala Land Incorporated disclosed that it had sold its 50% ownership of Alabang Commercial Center to the Madrigal family for P13.5 billion. The 17.5-hectare Alabang Town Center is a pioneer mall in Muntinlupa City that was developed by the Ayala Group under a joint venture with the Madrigal family. It currently has around 500 retail and office tenants. The purchase gives Rockwell Land the “opportunity to expand its footprint in a prime location with long-term redevelopment opportunities,” the company said. It adds 137,000 square meters of gross leasable area to Rockwell’s existing retail and office portfolio. Rockwell’s most famous project that symbolizes its target premium market is Rockwell Center Makati, home to some of the big names in Philippine business. Its Power Plant Mall is considered a premium retail and lifestyle destination, which is being replicated in other cities. A post shared by Power Plant Mall (@powerplantmall) “Over the years, the company has enhanced its retail developments by integrating experiential and lifestyle-oriented spaces into its masterplanning, supported by curated tenant mixes. These efforts have enabled Rockwell Land to establish a strong track record in delivering a high-end retail experience,” Rockwell Land said. The company also said that the purchase builds on Rockwell’s other retail expansion projects such as the Power Plant Nepo in Angeles City Pampanga; new retail spaces within Rockwell at IPI Center in Cebu City; and the Power Plant Mall Bacolod in Rockwell Center Bacolod. Rockwell’s main business is residential development of high-rise condominiums that cater to high-end buyers. Federico “Piki” Lopez has been vice-chairman of Rockwell Land since 2012. He is chairman and CEO of Lopez firms First Philippine Holdings, First Gen Corporation, and Energy Development Corporation. Last February, debt-saddled Lopez media and entertainment firm ABS-CBN Corporation sold 30,000 square meters of its 44,027-sqm-property in Sgt. Esguerra, Quezon City, to Ayala Land for P6.2 billion, allowing it to pay its outstanding bank loans. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Lopez family’s Rockwell buys Alabang Town Center from Madrigals for P21.6 billion

text: MANILA, Philippines – Do a regular Google search on AI technologies and their environmental impact. To say the least, the results are worrisome. Now, do a similar query on ChatGPT, Google Gemini, or other chatbots. You would have gotten a similar set of answers — only this time, you’ve used at least five times more power than a regular search. In June, a United Nations report found that four Big Tech firms (Amazon, Microsoft, Alphabet, and Meta) saw their indirect carbon emissions rise by 150% from 2020 to 2023 as their AI operations expanded. To expand, that meant building more data centers — physical facilities housing computers and servers that store, process, and transmit data. Data centers are set to increase, not decrease, in the coming years. The International Energy Agency, in an April 2025 report, estimated that “electricity demand from data centers worldwide is set to more than double” by 2030, with AI being identified as the most significant driver. And in the United States, where new data centers are aggressively being built, communities are already being impacted: water supply is disrupted, and electricity costs grow as new data centers rise. In the Philippines, there is a growing push for the country to build more data centers, as the government pursues its digital transformation goals. We are for digital transformation, but given how we’ve seen the power-hungry nature of data centers, it’s important that before the supposed data center “boom” comes, sustainability and the effect on communities are given the most serious consideration right away. Already, our climate targets are a mess, and the building of these data centers — left to their own devices — may just become more part of the problem than a solution to progress. Currently, there are 35 data centers in the Philippines, according to datacentermap.com. And here is an important fact that compounds what could be a big problem if we build data centers without due considerations: it’s hot in the Philippines. A Rest of World (RoW) report in November 2025 found that the Philippines is among the 21 countries that operate data centers in some regions where the average annual temperature is above 27°C. The optimal range is from 18°C to 27°C. The RoW report highlights Singapore — Southeast Asia’s “digital core” where 72 data centers are located — and quotes PS Lee who leads the Sustainable Tropical Data Center Testbed: “In thermal terms, Singapore is almost ‘permanent peak summer’ for a data center…. Cooling is both technically harder and structurally more energy-intensive here than in most other data center hubs.” It’s a challenge that Singapore, through the academia and private firms, is now currently trying to solve, with the government having already mandated reduced water and energy consumption for data centers, RoW said. Lee, noting that other countries also have a similar climate profile, hopes that advances by the Testbed may be adopted as well by others in the future. “Many of the world’s fastest-growing digital economies — such as Jakarta, Manila, Ho Chi Minh City, and Mumbai — share similar hot and humid conditions,” Lee said. BusinessWorld reported in October that Department of Information and Communications Technology (DICT) Secretary Henry Aguda is looking to reach 1.5 gigawatts in total data center output by 2028. Currently, the country’s output is at around 200 megawatts. Regional leader Singapore has a capacity of 1.4 gigawatts, followed by Malaysia and Indonesia, both below 1,000 megawatts. Aguda said the DICT wants to promote the Philippines as a data center hub, and plans to round up investments from the US, amid rising global demand. The environmental impact of data centers again made headlines in the US just days ago when its Congress reformed its 1969 National Environmental Policy Act — which pushes for faster permitting for building data centers, at the expense of comprehensive environmental reviews. Days before that, more than 200 environmental groups were protesting, and demanding a halt to new US data centers, citing the aforementioned water shortage and electricity cost issues. In light of all this, how must the Philippines act? We’re a far, far cry from the data center capacity of the US currently rated at more than 53 gigawatts. But we’re also at a tipping point for data center expansion.
